‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•á‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß ‡§Æ‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§Ω‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•å ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•á ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•• ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§ß‡•å‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•• ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Æ‡•Ø‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ This type of mixed worship is discussed by Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa: 17 yatha vidhi-nisedhau ca muktam naivopasarpatah tatha na sprsatau ramopasakam vidhi-purvakam 438 284 The Difference between Mantras and the Holy Name O Uddhava, since there is no end to the branch of the Vedas deal- ing with ritualistic ceremonies (karma-k√§nda), which is limit- less in scope and volume, I shall discuss this topic succinctly and in due order. There are three types of systems for worshiping Me - Vedic, Tantric, and mixed. Among these three, one should duly worship Me specifically by that system that accords with one’s longing. (SB 11.27.6-7)18 Hear from Me how a person should worship Me with faith and devotion after first attaining the status of being twice-born, by following the scriptural injunctions appropriate for his specific level of qualification. The practitioner endowed with devotion should worship Me - without duplicity and with suitable para- phernalia - in his own guru, in the form of the deity, in the land cleared for sacrifice, in the fire, in the sun, in water, in his own heart, or in the twice-born. After cleaning one’s teeth, one should first of all bathe in order to purify the body. This bathing should be done by reciting both kinds of mantras [Vedic and Tantric]” and by smearing the body with mud. Undertak- ing a serious vow, the practitioner should worship Me, which purifies one of all karma, while simultaneously carrying out the duties enjoined in the Vedas, such as reciting sandhyƒÅ prayers. (SB 11.27.8-11) 20 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• The meaning of this description is clear. 18 na hy anto’nanta-parasya karma-kandasya coddhava sank·π£iptam var·πáayisyami yathavad anupurvasa·∏• vaidikas tƒÅntriko misra iti me tri-vidho makha·∏• trayanam ipsitenaiva vidhina mƒÅm samarcayet 19 Both Sridhara Svami and Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti take the word ubhayaih as qualifying mantrai·∏•. Taken together, they mean “by both kinds of mantras, 20 Vedic and Tantric” (ubhayair vaidikais tantrikais ca mantrai·∏•). yada sva-nigamenoktam dvijatvam pr√§pya purusah yatha yajeta mam bhaktya sraddhaya tan nibodha me arcayam sthandile’gnau va surye v√§psu hrdi dvije dravyena bhakti-yukto’rcet sva-gurum mam amayaya purvam snanam prakurvita dhauta-danto’nga-suddhaye ubhayair api ca snanam mantrair mrd-grahanadina sandhyopastyadi-karmani vedenacoditani me pujam tai·∏• kalpayet samyak sankalpa·∏• karma-pavanƒ´m 439 III The Practice of Bhakti Commentary IN THE previous anuccheda, Sri Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ made the point that dik≈üa in a Vaisnava mantra is a prerequisite for worshiping the deity of Bhagavan. This condition was not stipulated for the practices of hearing, singing, and remembering the name. A mantra consists of Bhagavan’s names, usually inflected in the dative or accusative case, with the addition of a few specialized words, such as namah (“I bow down”), prapadye (“I surrender”), and svƒÅhƒÅ (“I offer”). Thus, there is essentially no difference between the name and mantras. The question must then be raised, why is dik·π£a required for mantras but not for the name? ≈örƒ´ Jiva replies that sages, such as ≈örƒ´ Narada, have assigned cer- tain regulations to mantras required for the worship of the deity (≈õrƒ´ vigraha) so that people who worship the deity will not become unclean and lethargic in their habits. Visnu is the predominating devata of sattva, which signifies cleanliness and peacefulness. Con- sequently, He is to be worshiped with a clean body and a peaceful mind. The word upasana literally means “to sit in close proxim- ity.” To come close to Vi≈ü≈Üu, the worshipers must follow the rules of cleanliness. Therefore, sages such as Narada, who have delin- eated the process of deity worship in books like Narada Pa√±caratra, have established the basic requirements for such service. If one does not follow these rules, the aspired for perfection will not be obtained. Moreover, the worshiper would be required to under- take some form of prescribed atonement (praya≈õcitta) to counteract the flaws in worship. Mantras are of four types: siddha, s√§dhya, susiddha, and ari. Siddha-mantras bestow their results in due course of time, sadhya- mantras, by performing japa and homa, susiddha-mantras, by diksa alone, while ari-mantras counteract malevolent influences. These then have 16 further subdivisions, namely, siddha-siddha, siddha- sadhya, siddha-susiddha, siddha-ari, and so on. Based on a person’s birth star, there is a method to determine which type of a mantra is suitable for a particular person. It is for this reason that the birth constellation (janma-bha) is mentioned in the verse cited 440 284 The Difference between Mantras and the Holy Name from Krama-dipika. But this type of calculation is not applicable for Vaisnava mantras, especially not for the Gopala mantra. Although the above-mentioned considerations do not apply to Vaisnava mantras, a practitioner must still follow the rules and reg- ulations established by the sages and those adhered to in one’s own school. To do otherwise would be to exhibit a lack of respect for the previous acƒÅryas, which would thus counter the effort at its root. Ignorance of the principles is also not excused. ≈öri Rupa GosvƒÅmƒ´ advises all practitioners to follow the path of the sadhus (sƒÅdhu- vartmƒÅnuvartanam, BRS 1.2.74)21 Although detailed explanations of worship can be found in books like Krama-dipika and Hari-bhakti- vilƒÅsa, yet one should learn the specific process of one’s own school from one’s own guru. Worship is of three types, namely, Vedic, Tantric, and mixed. Not everything stated in the scriptural texts is applicable to everybody. Moreover, the worship should be carried out in conformity to one’s aspired for devotional mood (bhava). There are two divisions of arcanam - pure (kevalam) and mixed with ritual or prescribed action (karma-mi≈õram). The first type of worship is performed exclusively for the pleasure of Bhagavan and is unmixed with any duties related to a person’s status in society based on vocation (varna), such as a brahmana, and stage of life (a≈°rama), such as a brahmacarƒ´. This type of arcanam is enacted only by those who have taken complete shelter of Bhagavan. The second type of arcanam is mixed with karma, or duties related to social status. This type of worship is evidenced par- ticularly in the social environment of householder life (grhastha- asrama), and it is born of two different categories of faith- conventional (vyavahƒÅrika) and transcendental (paramarthika), the latter meaning that which is based on direct experience rooted in a minute investigation of scriptural truth (i.e., sastriya-≈õraddhƒÅ). Worship born of conventional faith is undertaken primarily by two types of people. The first are those who are excessively achievement-oriented, motivated by a desire for recognition and respect in society. Though engaged in arcanam as part of their 21 guru-padasrayas tasmat k·πõ·π£·πáa-dik·π£ƒÅdi-sik·π£a·πáam visrambhena guro·∏• seva sadhu-vartmanuvartanam 441 III The Practice of Bhakti public identity, they give greater importance to their social duties. Their interest is to remain part of mainstream society. This shows their lack of understanding and faith in the path of bhakti. The second of the two types of mixed conventional worshipers are those who learn about arcanam within the context of their family tradition. Since their faith is merely conventional and not rooted in sastra, they do not have authentic faith in the process of bhakti. As a consequence, they too engage in mixed worship (arcanam), while giving prominence to their social duties. In contrast to these two types of conventional worshipers, the practitioners who are endowed with transcendental faith in bhakti, yet who are still involved with family and society, continue to per- form their social duties (karma) simply to set an ideal for people in general. They do so in order that common people, who are not devoted to Bhagavan, do not abandon their duties by following their example. They are well established in society, and common people take them as their ideal. If such influential people do not tend to their prescribed karma, then common people will not do so either, nor will the latter engage in pure arcanam, because they lack the requisite faith. Thus, they will be led astray both from the path of karma as well as bhakti. 442 Anuccheda 285 Two Ways of Performing Karma As Worship ‡•®‡•Æ‡•´ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á IN NARADA PANCARƒÄTRA as well, the exact same point [that Vedic karma is not to be abandoned] is made by Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa at the beginning of His elucidation of the ≈õraddha ceremony for the forefathers: ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§â‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ ‡••‡•§ ‡•Æ‡•Ø‡•™ ‡•• ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•à‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•Æ‡•Ø‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O Narada, even a perfect being (siddha), who does not first exe- cute his socio-religious duties (laukika-dharma), brings about a deterioration of dharma through disruption of the social norms. Therefore, as long as the body remains, all those endowed with discriminating knowledge should endeavor to carefully preserve the socio-religious duties (lokacara) as originally established (yatha-sthita ). ( Narada PancarƒÅtra ) ’ ‡§è‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ- ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡•Å - 1 nƒÅcared yas tu siddho’pi laukikam dharmam agrata·∏• upaplavac ca dharmasya glanir bhavati narada viveka-j√±air ata·∏• sarvair lokacaro yatha sthita·∏• adeha-p√§t√§d yatnena rak·π£aniyah prayatnata·∏• 443 III The Practice of Bhakti For those who engage in worship mixed with prescribed duties (karma-mi≈õra-arcanam), there are two ways in which the ordi- nance for karma may be carried out. In Narada Pancaratra, it is enjoined that one should worship all living beings [includ- ing the forefathers] with the view that Bhagavan is present within them as the Supreme Immanent Self (antaryami). [This is the first manner of offering karma, in which the worship of Bhagavan is executed indirectly by the worship of other living beings.] In the Visnu-yamala, however, karma is prescribed in the following alternate manner: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§¶‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Æ‡•Ø‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The ritual of offering oblations of water to the forefathers should be performed only with water that has washed Bha- gavan Vi≈ünu’s feet. All other devatƒÅs should be propitiated only with food offered to Bhagavan Vis≈Üu. (Vis≈Üu-yamala)2 ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‚Äú‡§® ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•Ø‡•§‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ In this regard, however, it is to be noted that the Ganesa and Durga who are included in the worship of the [transcenden- tal] devas who constitute the outer circumference (ƒÅvarana) of Bhagavan’s [yoga] pitha - the sanctum sanctorum of His divine lƒ´lƒÅ - are eternal servants of Bhagavan in Vaikuntha, akin to Visvaksena. Therefore, the Ga·πáe≈õa and Durga [of Vaikuntha] are not the same Ga·πáe≈õa and DurgƒÅ whose forms are products of the extrinsic potency (maya-sakti) [and whose worship is popular among people in general]. This is evidenced from this statement in the Second Canto of Srimad Bhagavata: 2 vis≈Üu-p√§dodakenaiva pit·πõ·πáam tarpana-kriya visnor niveditannena yastavyam devatantaram 444 285 Two Ways of Performing Karma As Worship In Vaikuntha, there is no influence of the material gunas of rajas, tamas, or sattva mixed with these two. There is no supremacy of time and no presence of maya, to say nothing of any other material influences. The attendants of Bhagavan Hari, who are revered by the devas and asuras alike, are present there. (SB 2.9.10)3 ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§§‡•É- ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ Therefore, the Ganesa and DurgƒÅ who are eternal servants of Bhagavan in Vaikuntha are direct embodiments of the potency that is intrinsic to Bhagavan’s essential being (svarupa-bh≈´ta- ≈õakti). For this reason alone, in ≈öruti, Tantra, and elsewhere, the specific manifestation of Bhagavan’s intrinsic potency that is predominated by devotion (bhakti-√§tmaka) and bears the name of Durga is described as the presiding deity even for the group of mantras beginning with the eighteen-syllable mantra, which embodies the essential being of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa. ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á - This is brought out in a dialogue between ≈öruti and Vidya from Narada Pa√±caratra: 3 ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§æ ‡••‡•§ ‡•Æ‡•Ø‡•≠ ‡•§‡•§ The goddess of devotion (bhakti), who is the personified potency (prak·πõti) of Bhagavan and whose only wealth is divine service (bhajana), worships her beloved (priyam) [≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa]. This potency of His is very difficult to fathom. Therefore she, who is most dear (vallabha) to Bhagavan, being the very essence of complete aesthetic delight (akhanda-rasa), is celebrated by pravartate yatra rajas tamas tayoh sattvam ca misram na ca kala-vikramah na yatra maya kim utapare harer anuvrata yatra surasurƒÅrcita·∏• 445 III The Practice of Bhakti the sages as Durga [lit., “she who is difficult to approach or fathom”]. (Narada Pancaratra)* ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•á ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡•à‡§µ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‚Äú‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ Therefore, with the intent to assert the nondistinction (abheda) between Durga and Bhagavan, the Gautamiya-kalpa says: “K·πõ·π£·πáa is none other than Durga, and Durga is none other than K·πõ·π£·πáa.” But statements such as, “You are the supreme reigning God- dess (parame≈õƒÅni), the presiding deity of this mantra,” are made by some [i.e., the worshipers of Durga] who wish to propound the nondistinction between the worship of the phenomenal [pr√•k·πõta] Durga and that of the transphenomenal [aprak·πõta] DurgƒÅ, just as some propound the nondistinction between the worship of the gross universal form (Virat-purusa) and the Supreme, or MahƒÅ, Purusa. ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡•§ In this material world, Durga is a partial manifestation of the potency known as MƒÅyƒÅ, and under her direction, Durga is engaged in the service of protecting mantras. Thus, she acts as a servant of the aprak·πõta Durga, who is an aspect of Bhaga- v√§n’s intrinsic potency (cit-≈õakti), and not as the presiding deity of divine service (seva) [which is itself an aspect of the same intrinsic potency]. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á- The aprak·πõta Durga is referred to in the Uttara-khanda of Padma Purana in the description of the outer circumference (avara·πáa) of Vaikuntha, which is beyond mƒÅyƒÅ: 4 bhaktir bhajana-sampattir bhajate prakrti·∏• priyam jnayate’tyanta-du·∏•khena seyam prak·πõtir atmanah durgeti giyate sadbhir akhanda-rasa-vallabha 446 285 Two Ways of Performing Karma As Worship ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§ó‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Æ‡•Ø‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§ê‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡•à‡§ã‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Æ‡•Ø‡•Ø ‡•§‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•å‡§ï‡§∏‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¶‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§π ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¶‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Satya, Acyuta, Ananta, Durga, Visvaksena, Ganesa, Sankhani- dhi, and Padmanidhi constitute the auspicious fourth concen- tric circle in the sphere of Vaikuntha. The seventh circle is said by sages to be occupied by the guardians of the directions, who are situated in their respective posts: Indra in the east, Agni in the southeast, Yama in the south, Nair·πõti in the southwest, Varuna in the west, Vayu in the northwest, Soma in the north, and Rudra in the northeast. The Sadhyas, Maruts, Vi≈õvadevas, as well as the other devas in the transcendental abode (pare dhamni) are all eternal. But the devas who reside in the material heavenly planets (prƒÅk·πõta-loka) are not eternal, as implied in the Vedic mantra: “The devas who reside in heaven enhance the glories of [ephemeral] heaven.” (Padma Purana, Uttarakhanda 228.60, 64-66) 5 ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§®‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§∑‡§°‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•á- ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á- 5 satyƒÅcyutƒÅnanta-durga-visvaksena-gajananah sankha-padma-nidhi-loka≈õ caturthavaranam subham aindrakagneyayamyƒÅni nair·πõtam varunam tatha vayavyam saumyam aisanam saptamam munibhih smytam sadhya marud-ganas caiva visvedevas tathaiva ca nityah sarve pare dhamni ye canye ca divaukasah te vai prak·πõta-loke’smin na nityas tridasesvarah te ha nƒÅkam mahimanah sacanta iti vai srutih There is an alternate reading in verse 228.60 with the word smrtam in place of subham. In that case, the translation would be : “Satya and so on are said (smrtam) to constitute the fourth concentric sphere.” The translation with subham is given in the text that follows. 447III The Practice of Bhakti Moreover, the devas who reside in Vaikuntha are integrated por- tions (amsas) of Bhagavan, as stated in the Trailokya-sammohana Tantra in the beginning of the enumeration of the names of the different devatƒÅs who preside over the sixfold divisions (sad-anga) of the eighteen-syllable mantra: ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•å ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ß‡§∞‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¶‡•® ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Bhagavan Hari, who is the Supreme Deva of all the devas and who is dressed as a cowherd boy, is present everywhere. He is celebrated by different names only because of the different forms that He assumes. (Trailokya-sammohana Tantra) ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§≠‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡•á " ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡§™‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡•á” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡•Æ‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Therefore, unalloyed devotees should not be perturbed by the fact that the devas in Bhagavan’s spiritual abode bear the same names as their counterparts in the material world. Rather, unal- loyed devotees should honor the aprak·πõta-devas as eternal ser- vants of Bhagavan in Vaikuntha, such as Visvaksena. This is understood from statements that emphasize the defect in failing to honor them, as in these words of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa: 7 One whose self-concept (atma-buddhih) is rooted in this corpse- like body, which is constituted of the three elements, mucus, bile, and air; whose sense of relation (sva-dhi·∏•) is in his wife, children, and other kin; whose concept of divinity (ijya-dhih) is in earthen images; and whose notion of the sacred (tirtha- buddhi·∏•) is in the water of a river; but who never cherishes the sense of self, of relation, of divinity, and of the sacred, in regard to those who have realized the Absolute, is indeed an ass among cows. (SB 10.84.13)” 6 sarvatra deva-devo’sau gopa-vesa-dharo harih kevalam rupa-bhedena nama-bhedah prakirtita·∏• yasyatma-buddhi·∏• kunape tri-dhatuke sva-dhih kalatradisu bhauma ijya-dhih yat-tirtha-buddhi·∏• salile na karhicij janesv abhijnesu sa eva go-kharah 448 285 Two Ways of Performing Karma As Worship And in the following statement from the Uttara-khanda of Padma PurƒÅna: One who, after worshiping Sri Govinda, neglects to worship His devotees (tadiyan) should not be recognized as a genuine devotee (bhagavata); rather, he is regarded as nothing but a pretender. (Padma PurƒÅna, Uttarakhanda 253.177 ) 8 ‡§Ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•≠‡•§‡•®‡•Ø) - Consequently, the following words of ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa are spoken specifically in regard to the aprak·πõta-devas of Vaikuntha: ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¶‡•© ‡•• Situating Durga, Vinayaka, Vyasa, Visvaksena, one’s gurus, and the devas in their respective positions, one should worship them by offering water and other items. (SB 11.27.29)” ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§° ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö - The aprak·πõta-devas are again referred to in the latter half of the following statement from the Uttara-khanda of Padma Purana: ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¶‡•™ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¶‡•´ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¶‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• 8 9 Therefore, one should give up the worship of devas not men- tioned in the Vedas, and even those mentioned in the Vedas arcayitva tu govindam tadƒ´yan narcayet tu yah na sa bhagavato j√±eyah kevalam dambhikah smrtah durgƒÅm vinayakam vyƒÅsam visvaksenam gurun surƒÅn sve sve sthane tv abhimukhan pujayet prok·π£a·πáadibhi·∏• 449 III The Practice of Bhakti should not be worshiped as independent I≈õvaras. After worship- ing Bhagavan Hari, who is NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, the worshipful Supreme Deva of the entire cosmos, one should worship the devas who are situated in His encirclement (tad-√§varana). A Vaisnava should offer them Bhagavan Hari’s remnants and make obla- tions to them using Bhagavan’s remnants. (Padma PurƒÅ≈Üa, Uttara-khanda 253.104b, 105-107a)10 Commentary ≈öRI JIVA GOSVƒÄMI makes a pertinent remark about mixing ritual offerings (karma) with arcanam. Normally, karma involves wor- ship of the devas and forefathers. On the path of bhakti, however, Bhagavan is the sole entity to be worshiped. So how can bhakti accommodate the worship of anyone else? There are two methods prescribed in this regard. The first involves worshiping Paramatma within the devas or the forefathers. The second entails worshiping the devas and forefathers as devotees of Bhagavan. This topic was discussed earlier in Anuccheda 106. Related to the subject of worshiping the devas, Sri Jiva explains that in Vaikuntha as well, there are transphenomenal or aprak·πõta- devas, who go by the names of Ganesa and Durga. They are differ- ent, however, from the phenomenal or pr√§k·πõta Ganesa and Durga of this world. They are devotees and eternal associates of Bhaga- v√§n. They are worshiped along with Bhagavan. They are called avarana-devatas, or the gods who encircle Bhagavan in the yoga- pitha, or the sanctum sanctorum of His divine lila. They should not be disregarded or disrespected, considering them as phenomenal devas of this material world. The devas in Vaikuntha are all devotees and are expansions (amsas) of Bhagavan. By contrast, the devas in 10 tasmad avaidikanam ca devanam arcanam tyajet svatantra-pujanam yac ca vaidikƒÅnƒÅm api tyajet arcayitva jagad-vandyam devam narayanam harim tad-avarana-samsthanam devasya parito’rcayet harer bhuktava≈ùe≈üena balim tebhyo vinik≈üipet homam caiva prakurvita tac chesenaiva vaisnava·∏• 450 285 Two Ways of Performing Karma As Worship the material world are partial manifestations of those residing in Vaikuntha. Arcanam is a very elaborate procedure described in the Agama literature. But on the path of raga-bhakti, arcanam is based on love and not on sets of rules. This, however, does not mean that there are no rules. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi is explaining some of the basic concepts, but the exact process must be learned from one’s guru. Even in a book like Hari-bhakti-vilasa, which is written specifically for Vaisnavas, there are certain prescriptions that are not to be followed by a devotee pursuing the path of rƒÅgƒÅ-bhakti. 451 Anuccheda 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam 286.1 Worship of Bhagavan’s Yoga-pitha ‡•®‡•Æ‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ - ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ- ALTHOUGH Worship of the bh≈´tas, or ghosts, is prescribed as a limb (anga) of the worship of Bhagavan, such worship is not to be undertaken [by pure Vaisnavas], because the bhutas do not belong to the group of devatas who constitute Bhagavan’s sur- rounding entourage ( ƒÅvarana). Furthermore, worship of the bh≈´tas has been forbidden in the same section of Padma Purana: ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•å‡§ï‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¶‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The worship of Yak·π£as, Pisacas, and other residents of the celes- tial realms who eat meat and drink wine, is understood as equal to drinking wine. ( Padma Purana, Uttarakhanda 253.95 ) 1 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ- ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ 1 Therefore, the worship of other divinities whose worship is com- pulsory should not be undertaken with forbidden articles, such as wine, even though these items may be acceptable to them, as in the case of Sankar·π£a·πáa [Balarama] and other deities. yak·π£a·πáam ca pisacanam madya-mamsa-bhujam tatha divaukasanam bhajanam surapana-samam sm·πõtam 452 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•§ Then again, irreligion (adharma) and the three constituent gunas of material nature- sattva, rajas, and tamas-are included as part of the worship of Bhagavan’s sanctum sanc- torum (pitha-puj√§). Yet, the Padma Purana and the Svaya- mbhuva Agama make no explicit mention of this. As such, these attributes personified are not to be given any credence within the scope of such worship. ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ “‡§Ö‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ Some, however, offer a different explanation of adharma and other such attributes based on the Narada Pa√±caratra, as stated therein: “Irreligion (adharma), ignorance (aj√±ƒÅna), absence of detachment (avairagya), and impotence (anai≈õvarya) - these four, however, are employed for inauspicious purposes (a≈õre- yasi).” According to this statement, irreligion, ignorance, and so on are understood as potencies (≈õaktis) of the Immanent Self (antaryami) operating in people who manifest these traits. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ - ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ In the worship of Bhagavan’s sanctum sanctorum (pƒ´»õha-p√ºjƒÅ), it is thus appropriate that the shoes of Sri Guru are worshiped on the left side of Bhagavan, for it is said that the same Bha- gavƒÅn who is present in this world as ≈öri Guru in individual form (vya≈ü»õi-rupa), by means of His avataric descent as a devo- tee, also exists in Vaikuntha in that same feature [as ≈öri Guru] in His collective form (sama≈üti-rupa), as the totality of all gurus. Although He Himself is a direct avatara, He is present there in that form [as sama≈ü»õi-rupa-guru], being situated on His own [i.e., Bhagavan’s] left side in the yoga-pitha. 2 adharmadya-catuskam tu a≈õreyasi niyojanam 453 III The Practice of Bhakti ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§æ- ‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ã‡§π‡§®‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç - ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∂‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Furthermore, in regard to the worship of Bhagavan RƒÅma, √§vara·πáa-devatƒÅs such as Mainda and Dvivida should be under- stood as belonging to Bhagavan’s eternal abode and as such are eternal and pure. As evidence of the eternality of the uttama- bhƒÅgavatas’ presence amidst Bhagavan’s entourage (ƒÅvarana), we can cite the story of Akrura’s vision. When he went to bathe in the Yamuna River in order to recite the agha-mar·π£a·πáa- mantra, he saw ≈örƒ´ Prahlada and other uttama-bhƒÅgavatas encircling Bhagavan [SB 10.39.54]. The same Prahlada appeared as a calf [during the Svayambhuva-manvantara] when King Prthu milked the earth, which had assumed the form of a cow. Prahlada’s prior existence as an eternal associate of Bhagavan can thus be understood, since he had not yet taken birth at the time of P·πõthu. He was born of Hiranyakasipu only later in the Cak·π£usa-manvantara. ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ- ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§Æ‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø- ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ When, however, Bhagavan Rama or other avataras, who are each eternally manifest in their own respective transcendental abodes, appear in this world, other living beings, who are jivas invested with the sakti of Bhagavan’s eternal associates, such as Mainda and Dvivida, take birth to assist in His lil√§. It is to be understood, however, that the Mainda and Dvivida who were empowered jivas of this world became corrupted due to associa- tion with those like Bali, who was inimical to Bhagavan Rama’s devotee, Sugrƒ´va, and in a later millennium, due to the associ- ation of those like Narakasura, who was inimical to Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa. This sort of phenomenon occurs because the manifesta- tion (pr√§katya) of Bhagavan’s lilƒÅ to the people of this world is 454 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam possible only by a mixture of His eternal associates with jivas belonging to the material world. ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ó‡•ã‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ó‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ In the worship of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa in Gokula, Rukmini and oth- ers like her [who are not part of the Gokula lil√§] are mentioned as K·πõ·π£·πáa’s surrounding associates. It should be understood, however, that such associates are present there in the form of specific potencies (sakti-visesa) of Bhagavan who remain in an unmanifest state, like Vimala and others, but who do not become visible participants in His Gokula lila. Therefore, they are not described in the meditation on this particular lilƒÅ. ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ There are some devotional scholars, however, who consider the names of Rukmi≈Üƒ´ and others, mentioned in the description of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s surrounding associates in Gokula, simply as alternate names for ≈öri Radha and other associates of Bhagavan. ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É- ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Analogous to this is the fact that although Krsna in Vraja does not outwardly adopt the conch, disc, club, and other similar paraphernalia, devotees consider that K·πõ·π£·πáa holds them as sym- bols on the soles of His feet. Similarly, the Ganga and Yamuna Rivers are considered as the two inner sides of the doorway to the abode of Gokula, yet the Ganga does not flow there. In this instance, the worshipful Ganga is accepted as referring to MƒÅnasi Ganga, the well-known lake situated at Govardhana. In the same vein, Visvaksena and others who are mentioned as associates of Bhagavan in Gokula, in spite of being outside of this realm, are regarded as Bhadrasena and others situated within Gokula. 455 III The Practice of Bhakti ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§ó‡•ã‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ- ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ- ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á (‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•¶ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡•¶ ‡•´ /‡•¨‡•Æ) - Another instance of the same thing is the worship of Svetadvipa (“the White Island”) and the Ocean of Milk that surrounds it as part of the pitha-puja of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa, even though they are not situated in Vraja. In such worship, Svetadvipa is taken simply as another name for Krsna’s abode (dhƒÅma) of Goloka, and the Ocean of Milk is present there in the special form of an abundance of milk flowing from the millions of kama-dhenus, or wish-fulfilling cows. This is stated in the concluding portion of the description of Goloka found in Brahma-samhita: ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ú‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§ó‡•ã‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§≤‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§Ø‡•á ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¶‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ I worship Svetadvipa, where a vast ocean of milk flows from the surabhi cows, where time is not subject to passing away even for half an instant, and which is known as Goloka only to a few rare sages here in this world. (BS 5.56 ) 3 ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•á- ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π- ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É " (‡§®‡•É‡•¶ ‡§§‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§â‡•¶ ‡•´‡•ß‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ 3 Instances of the same thing found elsewhere should be under- stood in the same way. Similarly, the sun, the moon, and fire also exist in Gokula as transphenomenal entities (aprƒÅk·πõta- vastu), devoid of any debilitating properties of excessive heat sa yatra k·π£irabdhih sravati surabhibhya≈õ ca sumahan nime·π£ƒÅrddhakhyo va vrajati na hi yatrapi samaya·∏• bhaje svetadvipam tam aham iha golokam iti yam vidantas te santa·∏• ksiti-virala-cara·∏• katipaye 456 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam and cold. This is admitted because the [scriptural] denial of phe- nomenality (prƒÅk·πõtatvam) in the dhama of Bhagavan is simply to affirm that the truly existent objects (vastu) belonging to it are intrinsically endowed with all auspicious qualities. An instance [of the denial of phenomenality] is seen in the Nrsimha-tapani Upanisad: The supreme dhƒÅma of Bhagavan, who presides over the king of mantras, is that abode, where there is no misery, where the sun does not shine, the wind does not blow, the moon does not glow, the stars do not shine, fire does not burn, death does not enter, and where there are no defects. (Nrsimha-tapani Upani- ≈üad, Purva-khanda 5.9)* ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ Various associates of Bhagavan have thus been described by contextual correlation with the topic of redressing the mixture of conventional ritual elements (karma-mi≈õra) in the worship (arcanam) of BhagavƒÅn. Commentary IN THE previous anuccheda, Sri Jiva GosvƒÅmi described the worship of the devatƒÅs who constitute the outer circumference (ƒÅvarana) of Bhagavan’s yoga-pitha. This is part of arcanam, as described in the Tantra literature, such as Gautamiya Tantra, ≈öƒÅrada-tilakam, Krama-dipikƒÅ, and so on. Some of this discussion can also be found in Hari-bhakti-vilƒÅsa of ≈örƒ´ Sanatana GosvƒÅmi. As seen in Anuccheda 284, sage Avirhotra recommends that one should worship Bhagavan in accordance with the descriptions given in the Vedas and Tantras (SB 11.3.47). Tantric worship is especially recommended in Kaliyuga (SB 11.5.31). In his prayers to Vi≈ü≈Üu (SB 8.6.9), Brahma confirms that worship should be carried 4 tad va etat param dhama mantra-rajadhyapakasya yatra na du·∏•khadi yatra na suryo bhati yatra na vayur vati yatra na candramas tapati na yatra nak·π£atrani bhanti yatra nagnir dahati yatra na mrtyuh pravi≈°ati yatra na do·π£a·∏• 457III The Practice of Bhakti out both by Vedic and Tantric methods. While instructing Uddhava, ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa also recommends worship mixed with the Tantra process (SB 11.11.37, 11.27.7, 11.27.26, and 11.27.49). At present, the word tantra has negative connotations associ- ated with it. In India, people normally think that tantra implies some kind of black magic, and in the West, people take it to be related with enhanced sexual performance. But both ideas are far from the truth. In India, there have always been two systems of knowledge coming from two different sources, called Nigama and ƒÄgama. Nigama refers to the Vedas, and Agama, to the Tantras. The Nigama system is meant for those who belong to the var·πáa- ≈õrama classification of society and is primarily meant for the first three var≈Üas, namely, brahmanas, ksatriyas, and vaisyas. The Agama system, however, is applicable to all members of society, irrespec- tive of whether they belong to var·πáƒÅ≈õrama or not. Eligibility to follow the Nigama system is obtained through the ceremony of upanayana-samsk√§ra, whereas eligibility for the Agama system is by virtue of the samsk√§ra of dik·π£ƒÅ. The Vedas have three divisions, namely, karma-k√§nda, upƒÅsanƒÅ- kanda, and j√±ƒÅna-k√§nda. Karma-kanda recommends various types of ritual acts (yaj√±as), such as agnihotra, darsa, paur≈ÜamƒÅsa, catu- rmasya, and soma. The upƒÅsanƒÅ-kanda is related to bhakti, and jnana- kanda, to philosophical insight, or the immediate cognition of ulti- mate truth. The subject of the upasana-kanda is explained in detail in the Agamas. The Vedas speak of the worship of Agni and Soma, and the Agamas, of Sakti and Saktiman. The Agamas have the same authority as the Smrti-sastra, which includes the Puranas and Itihasas. The Agama, or Tantra, is of three types - Vaisnava, ≈†aiva, and ≈†akta. The first classification promotes the worship of Visnu, the second, of ≈öiva, and the third, of Devi or Durga. The Vaisnava Agama also has three divisions, namely, Pa√±caratra, BhƒÅgavata, and Vaikhanasa. The subjects dealt with in the Agama include mantroddhƒÅra, dik·π£a-vidhi, bh≈´ta-≈õuddhi, nyasa, dhyana, svadhyaya or japa, prayoga, carya, and mandira-nirmana. There are different ways to classify the subject matter of Tantra, as illustrated below: 458 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam Tantra texts are divided into four sections:

  1. Samanya-pada
  2. Mantra-pada 3. Kriya-pada
  3. Yoga-pada According to a slightly different classification given in Vis≈Üu- samhita, pp. 7-8, the four divisions are enumerated as follows:
  4. Jnana - knowledge and its nature.
  5. Yoga - concentration of the mind and the means of doing so. 3. Kriya the construction of temples and the consecration of temple murtis.
  6. Carya- religious rites and social observances. Worship based on the Vaikhanasa division of the Agama liter- ature can still be witnessed in temples in South India, such as the famous temple of Venkatesvara Balaji in Tirupati. The temples in Tamilnadu, such as that of ≈örƒ´ Rangam, follow the Pancaratra sys- tem of worship. Temples in North India, especially in the V·πõnda- vana area, follow the Bhagavata system of worship. So, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi is here giving some essential knowledge for the interested sƒÅdhakas. The temples constructed according to the Agama have the main deity in the center, called the yoga-pitha, and there are other deities of the associates of the main deity surrounding the latter. These are called avara·πáa-devatƒÅs, and their worship is called avarana-pujƒÅ. There are detailed descriptions of these devatas and the process of their worship. Some of the prescriptions are not applicable in the process of pure bhakti, even if found in the description of the yoga- pitha. ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi has thus provided guidelines as to what should be followed and what should be avoided. 459 III The Practice of Bhakti 286.2 Bhuta-suddhi ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§≤- ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•å‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ç- ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ To the best of my ability, I shall now explain bh≈´ta-suddhi, or “purification of the constituent elements,” as performed by pure devotees. In this regard, those whose one and only object of attainment is to serve Bhagav√§n, should perform bh≈´ta-≈õuddhi up to the point of contemplating the body of an eternal asso- ciate of Bhagavan, which is the vehicle that makes possible the specific service of Bhagavan that one cherishes. This type of bh≈´ta-suddhi is recommended because it is favorable to one’s devotional aspiration (nijƒÅbhila·π£ita-bhagavat-seva). ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ê‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø- ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ According to this understanding, wherever it is recommended that one should meditate on oneself as identical with the form of Bhagavan whom one cherishes (nij√§bhƒ´·π£·π≠a-devatƒÅ), one should rather envision oneself as an associate (parsada) of Bhagavan, because pure devotees abhor ahangrahopasana, or the worship of oneself as Bhagavan. The oneness (aikyam) between Bhaga- v√§n and His eternal associates that this refers to is in a general sense only, inasmuch as the bodies of Bhagavan’s associates are integrated portions (amsas) of visuddha-sattva, or “unal- loyed being,” which is a functional capacity (vrtti) of Bhagavan’s intrinsic potency, known as cit-sakti.5 5 The oneness spoken of here is in terms of the nature and essence of being, since both Bhagavan and His eternal associates have forms constituted of unalloyed being (visuddha-sattva), which is the very essence of Bhagavan’s own intrinsic potency (cit-sakti). The oneness is thus of the conscious part (amsa) in relation to the conscious whole (amsi). 460 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ú‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç – ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•å- ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ In regard to nyasa, or the mental assignment of deities to dif- ferent parts of the body, such as the assignment of Kesava to the lower part of the body, the practitioner should meditate on the specific form of the deity in question, utter the mantra that pertains to that deity, and then merely touch the corresponding area of the body. One should not think, however, that the deity of the mantra is physically installed in that particular limb of the body, because it would be inappropriate for devotees to do So. ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ In the opinion of the yogis, Bhagavan is to be meditated upon as situated on the lotus of the heart, whereas for the devotees, the principal meditation is on ≈örƒ´ Bhagavan priorly present in His own abode, because it is written [in Tantra], “One should remember ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa in the enchanting land of V·πõnda- vana” (smared v·πõndavane ramye). Consequently, internalized mental worship (mƒÅnasa-p≈´jƒÅ) also involves contemplation of Bhagavan specifically in His own abode. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç " ‡§ó‡•ã‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï ‡§è‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ñ‡§ø- ‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§É " ( ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•¶ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡•¶ ‡•´‡•§‡•™‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The meditation on Bhagavan in the form of the kƒÅma-gayatri mantra makes reference to Bhagavan situated within the orb of the sun. In this case also, one should meditate on Bhagavan situated in His own abode, because it is emphatically stated in Brahma-samhita: “≈örƒ´ Govinda, who is the Immanent Self of all living beings, resides exclusively in Goloka” (BS 5.37). In this statement, the word eva [qualifying Goloka] means “only there.” goloka eva nivasaty akhilatma-bhutah 6 461 III The Practice of Bhakti The Lord of V·πõndƒÅvana [≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa] does not reside within the orb of the sun in His original form, but He is present there in the form of a super effulgent image (tejomaya-pratima). ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡•§ In internalized worship (antah-puja) executed through the offering of external objects, a prescription is found to worship the flute and other articles [by placing them on one’s own limbs]. In this regard, because the worshiper’s limbs are merged in the effulgence of Bhagavan’s limbs, and because Bhagavan thus per- vades the worshiper’s limbs, one should contemplate the flute as being placed only in Bhagavan’s mouth and not in one’s own. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç - ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ The display of mudras, or gestures, involving the use of Bhaga- van’s ornaments, such as the flute, which is done by holding the flute to one’s own mouth, should be performed simply in the spirit of pleasing Bhagavan by showing Him the articles that are dear to Him. One should not imagine these articles, however, as placed on one’s own limbs for the reason previously discussed [because this would constitute the defect of ahangrahopƒÅsanƒÅ]. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞- ‡§ï‡§ü‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ In internalized mental worship (mƒÅnasa-pujƒÅ), although the meditation on Bhagavan accompanied by His associates and lilƒÅs refers to events that occurred in the past, this meditation is not imaginary, but ontologically real. This is so because the lil√§s that took place and the associates who were present at the time of Bhagavan’s appearance in this world eternally exist in unlimited number and variety in His own abode, beyond the vision of this world (aprakata). 462 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ “‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‚Äú‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡•ã‡§ü‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ | ‡•ß‡•™ | ‡•¨‡•ß ) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡•å‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ The asuras, however, who participated in Bhagavan’s lƒ´lƒÅs in this world, are not present as conscious entities in Bhaga- van’s aprakata-dh√§ma. Rather, they are understood to exist there as diagrammatic [or “holographic”] replicas (yantramaya- pratimas)? This is evidenced from the fact that [in the apraka»õa- dhƒÅma as well] Krsna and His friends regularly enact the lil√§s of His various avataras [including the battles with various asuras] in a spirit of pure enjoyment, as expressed by Sri Suka: In this manner, K·πõ·π£·πáa and Balarama passed their childhood in Vraja by performing childlike pastimes, such as hide-and-seek, building bridges [in imitation of Bhagavan RƒÅma], and jumping like monkeys [who crossed the ocean to assist Rama in His battle against the demon Ravana]. (SB 10.14.61)8 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The eternality of each and every one of Bhagavan’s lil√§s was logi- cally demonstrated in Bhagavat Sandarbha [Anuccheda 47.2] and elsewhere. 7 It is generally understood that asuras cannot exist in the aprakata-dhama, since no conscious entities in that transcendental abode can have a mood antagonistic to Bhagavan. Yet, if there was no sense or bare idea of their existence at all, there would be no possibility of enacting any lilas involving them. And if the lilas involving the asuras did not take place in some form in the apraka·π≠a-dhama, this would contradict the eternality of those lilas. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va solves the dilemma by explaining that the asuras are present there not as conscious entities but as diagrammatic or “holographic” replicas (yantramaya-pratimas). In this connection, our Gurudeva, Sri Sri Haridasa Sastri Maharaja, comments in his Hindi translation of Bhakti Sandarbha that when Krsna and His friends want to taste a particular rasa, these diagrammatic (citrarkita) asuras become activated to enable the corresponding lila to unfold. By using the word citrankita as a synonym for yantramaya, ≈†ƒÅstrƒ´ Maharaja makes it clear that the asuras in Goloka are “pictographs,” or in the modern space-age sense, something akin to “holograms.” 8 evam vihƒÅrai·∏• kaumaraih kaumaram jahatur vraje nilayanai·∏• setu-bandhair markatotplavanadibhi·∏• 463 III The Practice of Bhakti ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç " ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å- ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¶‡•Ø ‡•• Now we will point out the glory of internalized mental worship (mƒÅnasa-p√ºjƒÅ), as expressed by ≈öri NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa in Narada Pa√±ca- ratra: “This yoga of internalized meditative worship (mƒÅnasa- yoga) removes old age, disease, and fear.”” And in this statement as well: O enlightened sage, Narada, I am pleased with that person who even once engages in this [m√§nasa-yoga] with supreme bhakti in accordance with the recommended order and procedure. (Narada Pancaratra) 10 ‡§è‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç “‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•à‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡•´‡•¶ ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ This manasa-pujƒÅ is sometimes taken up independent of any other process, because the deity conceived within the mind (manomayi-m√ºrti) has been ordained as one of the eight distinct forms of the deity. Furthermore, by use of the word va, “or,” in the following statement, the sage Avirhotra has certified inter- nal worship as a viable option: “One should worship Bhagavan with available articles either in the external form of the deity or within the heart (h·πõdaye va)” (SB 11.3.50).“11 9 Commentary Bhuta-suddhi, or purification of the elements that constitute the material body, is performed before one begins the act of worship ayam yo manaso yogo jara-vyadhi-bhayapahah 10 yas caitat paraya bhakty√§ sak·πõt kuryan mahƒÅmate kramoditena vidhina tasya tusyamy aham mune “arcadau hrdaye vapi yatha-labdhopacarakai·∏• 464 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam proper. This is necessary, because the deity is beyond the gunas of prakrti, while our bodies are made of the gunas. To undertake worship, one must have the same nature as the deity, devo bh≈´tva devam yajeta, or otherwise stated, one who is not divine should not worship the deity, nadevo devam arcayet. There is an elaborate procedure of bh≈´ta-suddhi described in the Tantra and Pancaratra. The process followed in Hari-bhakti-vilƒÅsa (5.63-73) follows the Trailokya-sammohana-tantra. The procedure there calls for one to first desiccate the material body by force of the imagination, then to burn the body to ashes with the fire aris- ing from the heart, and then to pour spiritual ambrosia over the elements to create the spiritual body and invest it with life. This is done in the same manner in which one transforms the mate- rial elements in a deity to make it suitable for Bhagavan’s presence. Included in the process is the elevation of one’s consciousness to the thousand-petalled lotus in the cranium. Another important work that influences the arcana-m√§rga in Gau·∏çƒ´ya Vaisnavism is Krama-dipika (1.8), which also includes instructions for prƒÅnƒÅyƒÅma. The Trailokya-sammohana-tantra concludes that bh≈´ta-suddhi can be performed even through a mental process alone, by entering the body through meditation without the other rituals involved. PrƒÅ·πáƒÅ- yama and other rules are to be set by the customs of the particular school or sampradaya!2 Sadhana-dipika explains that the method of bhuta-suddhi taught by Rupa GosvƒÅmƒ´ is that one should first address Sankar·π£ana, the presiding deity of ego (ahankara), and pray to Him to make one’s body suitable for worship!3 ≈örƒ´la Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ similarly advises that on the path of pure or raga-bhakti, a practitioner should think of himself or herself as having a requisite spiritual body for service. This type of deliberation is favorable for attaining the ultimate per- fection of the bhakti path, because the bhakti practitioner’s final 12 kim va cintana-matrena bh≈´ta-suddhim vidhaya tam pranayamams tata·∏• kuryat sampradayanusarata·∏• 13 ≈õri vrajƒÅcƒÅrya-srimad-rupa-gosvami-bhajanƒÅnusƒÅre≈Üa. ahank√§rƒÅdhi·π£·π≠hƒÅt·πõtvƒÅd bhuta-suddher adhidevaya sarkarsanaya nama·∏•, he sankarsana! asya janasya deha-rupe≈Üa parinatam bh≈´ta-pa√±cakam yatha sadya·∏• sudhyed upasanopayuktam syat tatha krp√§·πÅ kuru. 465 III The Practice of Bhakti aspiration is to become an associate of Bhagavan and to serve Him with devotion. In this regard, one can contemplate the following prayer of Sri Caitanya Mahaprabhu: I am not a brahmana, nor a ksatriya, nor a vaisya, nor a sudra. I am not a brahmacarƒ´, nor a householder, nor a person retired from social involvement, nor an ascetic monk. Rather, I am a servant of the servant of the servants of the lotus feet of the lover of the gopis, ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa, who is an ocean of immortal nectar overflowing with powerfully ascendant waves of unmitigated supreme bliss. (Padyavali 74, Caitanya Caritam·πõta 2.13.80)14 Within the process of worship (arcanam), we also find instruc- tions that the worshipers should identify themselves with their worshipful deity. This is called ahangrahopƒÅsana, or worship of oneself as the divine. This, however, is forbidden on the path of pure bhakti, because it runs counter to the very nature of the loving relation that exists between the bhakta and Bhagavan. Nyasa is another part of bh≈´ta-suddhi. It is of various types, such as anga-nyasa, kara-nyasa, mƒÅt·πõka-nyasa, and ke≈õavƒÅdi-nyasa. Nyasa literally means “placement.” In the context of worship, it means to place particular deities or seed mantras on one’s own body by uttering appropriate mantras and meditation. ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi forbids placing a deity on the lower part of the body. The navel is the center of the body, and anything below it is considered base and impure. Therefore, instead of actually placing the deity on the lower part of the body, one should simply meditate on the deity in question, utter the corresponding mantra, and touch the lower part of the body with one’s right hand. See Hari-bhakti-vilƒÅsa 5.89-165 for more extensive descriptions of the various kinds of nyasa. As far as meditation on Bhagavan is concerned, it should be per- formed by contemplating Bhagavan as situated in His own abode and not in one’s heart or in the orb of the sun. Meditation on Bha- gavan in the heart is the prescribed method for the yogis, while the 14 naham vipro na ca narapatir napi vaisyo na sudro naham varni na grhapati na vanastho yatir va kintu prodyan-nikhila-p√ºr·πáƒÅm·πõtƒÅbdher gopi-bhartu·∏• pada-kamalayor dasa-d√§s√§nudasa·∏• 466 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam adherents of the karma-m√§rga conceive of Bhagavan as situated in the sun’s orb. For bhaktas, however, Bhagavan is a person residing in His own abode. The heart is too constricted a place for Him, and the sun is uninhabitable. Mudras are symbolic hand gestures, which represent certain articles or convey some intention of the worshiper. Mudras are shown to the deity for His pleasure. They are called mudrƒÅs because they bring happiness to the deity (mudam ratiti mudra). There are many mudras, but for the worship of Krsna, five in particular are recommended: ve≈Üu, vanamƒÅlƒÅ, ≈õrƒ´vatsa, kaustubha, and bilva (Hari- bhakti-vilƒÅsa 5.166-167). Kara-kacchapika, “the turtle mudra,” is also recommended, particularly for bh≈´ta-suddhi. Mudras are also shown to the deity to invite Him to be present, to be seated, to accept bhoga, and so on. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ recom- mends that the mudras that signify special ornaments of Bhagavan, such as ve≈Üu or vanamalƒÅ, should not be placed on one’s own mouth or neck respectively, but should only be shown to the deity for His pleasure. The reason for this is that if they are placed on one’s own body, it would constitute a form of ahangrahopasana, which is forbidden. Mudras can also be stamped on the body by using hot metal branding irons. This is called tapta-mudra. It is recommended that this be done on sayana-ekƒÅdasi or dvadasi. The use of mudras should be learned from one’s guru. One should follow the process established in one’s own sampradaya (Hari-bhakti-vilƒÅsa 4.301). In commenting on Bhakti-rasƒÅm·πõta-sindhu 1.2.296, ≈örƒ´ Vi≈õ- vanatha Cakravarti writes that a devotee following rƒÅgƒÅnugƒÅ-bhakti should not engage in ahangrahopƒÅsana, display mudrƒÅs, perform nyasa, meditate on Dvaraka, or worship Rukmi·πáƒ´, even if these practices are prescribed in the Agama-sastra as part of arcana- bhakti. The reason for this is that these practices are not con- ducive to the mood of devotion in Vraja. On the whole, Gau·∏çƒ´ya Vaisnavas are disinclined to those rituals that do not directly inspire remembrance of Krsna in Vraja or devotion to Him. In this regard, the Gaudiyas cite the legend of RanabƒÅrƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa- dƒÅsa. Although he was residing in Vraja, a desire arose within him 467III The Practice of Bhakti to visit the holy places, particularly Dvaraka, where he was per- suaded to have his body branded with the symbols of Visnu (tapta- mudra). On his return, he was no longer able to become absorbed in lila-smaranam in the same manner as he previously did before visiting Dvaraka. Being thus deprived of his internal service to RadhƒÅrƒÅnƒ´, he became very morose. Then, Radha informed him in a dream, “Your action now makes you a member of Rukmini’s entourage.” He was heartbroken and gave up his life in the fire of separation. Till today, the day of Ranabari’s self-immolation is cele- brated in his village to honor him. These rituals of mudra and nyasa are felt to be in the mood of awe and reverence and not in tune with the mood of worship found in VrndƒÅvana. 286.3 Loci of Worship ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ- ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç - ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡•à‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç “‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É " ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ Now we will discuss the loci of worship (puja-sthƒÅnas), mean- ing the places or “the seats” of Bhagavan’s appearance for the purpose of worship. These locations are of various types. In this regard, ≈öƒÅlagrama [the sacred stone that embodies the pres- ence of Bhagavan Vis≈Üu], is to be conceived as the existential substratum (adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna) of Bhagavan’s form (ƒÅkƒÅra) [and not as the actual form itself], because SalagrƒÅma’s form is different from that of Bhagavan. This is evidenced in the following state- ment: “Bhagavan Hari is present wherever the ≈öƒÅlagrƒÅma stone is found.” ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç - ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï- ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç “‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡•™‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ In this matter, to meditate on the existential seat (adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna) of Bhagavan [i.e., ≈öalagrƒÅma] as the place of manifestation of one’s specific cherished form of Bhagavan yields perfection 468 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam (siddhi) in a highly efficacious manner, because in that par- ticular seat, Bhagavan manifests the coveted form [of His own accord (svabh√§vika-bhavata·∏•)] without any effort [on the part of the sadhaka]. This is substantiated by the following statement: “One should worship Bhagavan in the form that is according to one’s longing” (SB 11.3.48).15 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§•‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§Æ‡§•‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É” ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§µ‡•à‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§•‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä- ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§•‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ In contrast, however, Mathura, [DvƒÅrakƒÅ, and V·πõndƒÅvana] are the supreme existential seats (maha-adhisthanas) of ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa. [Likewise, other holy places, such as Ayodhya, are the sup- reme existential seats of His avataras, such as Rama.] This is understood from statements such as this: “Mathura is that abode wherein Bhagavan Hari is eternally present” (SB 10.1.28).16 Another reason why these abodes are considered as supreme seats is because in the Gopala-tapani and other scriptures, Mathura, V·πõndƒÅvana, and other holy places have been described as part of the supreme majesty (vaibhava) of the dhyeya- the Entity to be meditated upon [i.e., ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa] - through the mantras that denote Him in His various forms. Even if the deity is established in a different location (adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna), the worshiper should manifest the holy land of Mathura or other abodes through meditation and contemplate his cherished form of Bhagavan as residing in the corresponding sacred place. ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø - ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç “‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ 15 labdhvƒÅnugraha ƒÅcƒÅryat tena sandarsitƒÅgamah maha-puru≈üam abhyarcen murtyabhimatayatmanah 16 mathura bhagavan yatra nityam sannihito harih 469 III The Practice of Bhakti In contrast to the form of Salagrama, the deity forms (pratimƒÅs) of Bhagavan are meditated upon as nondifferent from Bhaga- van’s own form, because these forms are identical in appear- ance. Furthermore, to think of the deity as different from Bha- gavan’s own form is offensive, as understood from this lament of Andha Muni [whose son was accidentally killed by MahƒÅrƒÅja Dasaratha]: “Or, have I at any time considered the deity of Bha- gavan Hari to be made of stone [as a result of which this calamity has befallen me]?“17 ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‚Äú‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•®‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‚Äì ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ- ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa has also pointed out the oneness of Bhagavan and the deity in these words: “The deity (prati·π£·π≠hƒÅ), which is the seat of manifestation of ParamƒÅtmƒÅ (jƒ´va-mandiram), is of two types - moving and stationary” (SB 11.27.13). In this verse, the word pratistha means “the deity” (pratima). In the compound jiva-mandiram, the word jiva means “of He who animates the living beings” (jivasya jivayitu·∏•), or in other words, “of Param- atma, the Supreme Immanent Self,” meaning “of Me” (mama). The word mandiram, lit., “a dwelling place,” means “the seat of manifestation (aspadam) of that form (ƒÅkƒÅra) which is one with My limbs and subsidiary bodily parts” (anga-pratyanga). ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ Alternatively, the word pratisthƒÅ may refer to the ritual act (karma) by which the above-mentioned deity is established as a seat of manifestation, one in form with My limbs and subsidiary bodily parts. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§π‡§Ø‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å “‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç - 17 sila-buddhi·∏• krta kim va pratimayam harer maya 470 286 Further Considerations Regarding Arcanam In Hayasir·π£a Pa√±caratra, we find this mantra, invoking Bha- gavan’s presence in the deity: “O Bhagavan Vis≈Üu, please be present in this deity.” Immediately following this, we find another mantra [indicating the basis of the nondistinction between the form of the deity and that of Bhagavan]: ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•Ø‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O Bhagavan, whatever may be Your supreme existential real- ity (parama-tattva) and Your form of unalloyed conscious- ness (j√±ƒÅna-maya-vapu), let all that be merged as one in this deity. May You now awaken in and as this form.
