These descriptions are generally in the mood of ai≈õvarya worship, in which Bhagavan is dealt with and served with great reverence in His majestic feature. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ gives some guidelines here for the devotees following the mood of pure love. They should look upon the deity as a human being with human requirements, and not as God Almighty, who is com- plete in Himself and does not need our service. He gives two exam- ples from Krama-dipika and advises the prema-bhaktas to adjust the instructions in accordance with Krsna’s human-like play (nara- lƒ´lƒÅ). ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi recommends that the meaning of the mantra used in meditation should be conceived in correspondence with the practitioner’s aspired for aim. One is not limited to the literal meaning of the mantra. As an example, Sri Jiva refers to an eight- syllable mantra that does not employ the fourth case. The fourth case is indicative of surrender. In uttering a mantra of this type, one can still conceive of its meaning as implying surrender to the deity. The most popular eight-syllable mantra is the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa mantra. It contains the indeclinable nama·∏• (lit., “obeisances”), which sig- nifies surrender. The words nama·∏•, svƒÅhƒÅ, svadhƒÅ, saranam, and prapadye all signify surrender to the worshipful deity, and for the most part, one or more of these words will be included in all mantras. It is not known which eight-syllable mantra ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ had in mind, but one that does fit his description of not employing the fourth case is “sri krsnah saranam mama,” the princi- pal mantra of the Vallabha-sampradaya. It means, “≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa is my shelter.” While reciting this mantra, one can think of its meaning, “I surrender to Sri Krsna,” or “I take shelter of ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa.” If it so happens that a particular mantra is missing a word or case that directly signifies surrender, the practitioner should nonetheless meditate on the principle of surrender as implicit in the mantra. 513 III The Practice of Bhakti The meaning of a mantra is flexible according to one’s sankalpa, or resolve. A person desiring pure bhakti should take the meaning of his or her mantra as a prayer for pure bhakti. ≈örƒ´ Jiva mentions that bhakti can be performed either with a pure or an impure intention. The pure intention is to execute bhakti only to attain love of God. The impure intention is to acquire some type of material gain in this life or after death. At the end of this anuccheda, he gives an example of impure worship. An example of pure worship is given in the next anuccheda. 514 Anuccheda 297 Bhagavan Is Attained by Pure Worship ‡•®‡•Ø‡•≠ | ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß/‡•®‡•≠/‡•´‡•© ) - [SIMILARLY, pure worship is indicated by its result], as ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa said: ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§≤‡§≠‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•©‡•´ ‡•• One who worships Me according to the injunctions already mentioned attains bhakti-yoga, and by performing bhakti-yoga without any motive (nairapeksyena), one attains Me directly. (SB 11.27.53)1 ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• The word nairapeksyena, “without any motive,” [qualifying bhakti-yogena] means “causeless” or “free from all material con- ditions” (nirupƒÅdhina). Bhakti-yogena means, “through love” (prem≈ÜƒÅ), and this causeless bhakti-yoga ensues from worship conducted in this manner. This is clear from Krsna’s statement in the second line of the verse. 1 mƒÅm eva nairapeksyena bhakti-yogena vindati bhakti-yogam sa labhata evam yah pujayeta mam 515 516 III The Practice of Bhakti Commentary THE RESULT of an undertaking is dependent upon one’s motive, sankalpa. Bhakti can grant anything material or spiritual, as Krsna assures Uddhava in the Bhagavata (SB 11.20.32-33). In the previous verse (SB 11.27.49), impure worship was demonstrated by the attain- ment of material fruits in this life and the next. Now in this verse, pure worship is indicated by the attainment of causeless devotion, which leads to the direct attainment of Krsna Himself. Anuccheda 298 Eligibility for Worship ‡•®‡•Ø‡•Æ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ THERE are numerous other practices that are considered as limbs (angas) of worship, such as decorating one’s body with the marks of a Vaisnava, accepting the garlands used by Bha- gav√§n, and honoring the water that washed Bhagavan’s feet. The individual importance of all these various practices can be gleaned from thousands of different scriptural statements. ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§É (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•≠‡•§‡•™) - Now we will determine who is eligible to perform worship. In this regard, Uddhava said to Bhagav√§n K·πõ·π£·πáa: ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§¶ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•©‡•¨ ‡•• O Manada [You who are respectful to all], this indeed [i.e., the worship of You (tvad-arcanam)]’ is approved for persons belong- ing to all vocational classes (varnas), all stages of life (a≈õramas), and for women and sudras as well. I consider it to be the fore- most of all practices [sadhanas] that lead to the ultimate good. (SB 11.27.4)3 1 ≈örƒ´ Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti 2 ≈örƒ´ Giridhara 3 etad vai sarva-var·πáƒÅnam asramanam ca sammatam ≈õreyasam uttamam manye stri-sudrƒÅnam ca manada 517III The Practice of Bhakti ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á " The compound sarva-var·πá√§n√§m, “for all vocational classes,’ refers to the three higher classes [as the sudras have been men- tioned separately]. The same point, that worship is the right of all human beings, is made in the Smrty-artha-sara and the Vaisakha-mƒÅhƒÅtmya of Padma PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•©‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•©‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•Ä ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•©‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ While contemplating their Supreme Master (pati) within the heart, women and sudras should worship Bhagavan Visnu with reverence by the process described in the Agama. ≈†≈´dras should also worship Bhagavan specifically by mantras composed of the names of Bhagav√§n. Everyone can worship Bhagavan Visnu by the path of the Agama that accords with the Vedas. Women in general, as well as those in particular who are devoted to their husbands,* are also eligible to worship Bhaga- van Vis≈Üu. This is an eternal injunction of the Veda. (Padma Purana, Srsti-khanda 84.52-54)5 4 5 According to Smrti-sastra, devotion to the husband is equated with the worship of God, which would obviate the need for such worship. Here, however, it is said that even women who are devoted to their husbands have the right to worship Bhagavan. agamoktena margena stribhih sudrais ca pujanam kartavyam ≈õraddhaya visnos cintayitva patim hrdi sudrƒÅnam caiva bhavati nƒÅmnƒÅ vai devatarcanam sarve cagama-margena kuryur vedanusarina stri≈Üam apy adhikaro’sti visnor aradhanadisu pati-priya-hitanam ca srutir esa sanatani 518 298 Eligibility for Worship ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á- In Visnu dharma PurƒÅna, it is said: ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•å ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡•§‡•§ ‡•Ø‡•™‡•¶ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•™‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§‡•§ ‡•Ø‡•™‡•® ‡•• ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•™‡•© ‡•• Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa is pleased with a person who has bhakti of the following eight varieties toward his worshipful deity, his mantra, and the guru who gave the mantra: to be affectionate toward BhagavƒÅn’s devotees, to approve of Bhagavan’s worship, to worship Bhagavan regularly with a pure mind, to give up hypocrisy for the sake of Bhagavan, to develop attachment to hearing Bhagavan’s narrations, to engage the limbs of the body in the service of Bhagavan, to remember Bhagavan constantly, and to make Bhagavan’s name one’s very life. If these eight types of bhakti are found even in a mleccha, that person becomes a sage and an abode of truth and dignity. (Visnu- dharma PurƒÅ·πáa) ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•á - Furthermore, it is said in Tattva-sƒÅgara: 6 ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•™‡•™ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ devatayam ca mantre ca tatha mantra-prade gurau bhaktir asta-vidha yasya tasya krsna·∏• prasidati tad-bhakta-jana-vatsalyam pujayam cƒÅnumodanam sumana arcayen nityam tad-arthe dambha-varjanam tat-katha-sravane ragas tad-arthe cariga-vikriya tad-anusmaranam nityam yas tan-nƒÅmopajivati bhaktir asta-vidha hy e·π£a yasmin mlecche’pi vartate sa muni·∏• satyavadi ca kirtiman sa bhaven narah 519 III The Practice of Bhakti Just as bell-metal is turned into gold by an alchemical pro- cess, human beings become twice-born by the process of dik·π£ƒÅ. (Tattva-s√§gara)’ ‡§Ö‡§• “‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•®‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ ‡§µ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï ‡§è‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡•ã- ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ “‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• In the section of verses from Srimad Bhagavata beginning with SB 11.5.21, it is stated that in different yugas, there are different manifestations of Bhagavan and, correspondingly, different processes of worship. This is applicable in a relative sense but not absolutely, because scripture itself prescribes the worship of other forms of Bhagav√§n, distinct from the four forms rec- ommended for the four yugas. If other forms could not be wor- shiped simultaneous to the yuga-avataras, there would be no time at which the worship of other forms could take place. It is also understood from scripture that in all yugas, worshipers of all manifestations of Bhagavan are to be found. Consequently, it is established that all manifestations of Bhagavan can be wor- shiped at all times by everyone, in accordance with individ- ual taste. Thus, the conclusion expressed in SB 11.27.4, that the worship of K·πõ·π£·πáa is approved for all, is universally accepted. Commentary THERE are numerous limbs (angas) of bhakti. The glory of these various limbs is expounded in different Puranas and Tantra liter- ature. Some of them are described in Bhakti-ras√§mrta-sindhu, in the first division, second wave. Hari-bhakti-vil√§sa, however, gives many more details. One can refer to it for further specifics. After concluding the description of deity worship, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ cites 7 yatha ka√±canatam yati kamsyam rasa-vidhanata·∏• tatha dƒ´ksa-vidhanena dvijatvam jayate n·πõ·πáam 520 298 Eligibility for Worship verses from various scriptures to establish that every human being has the right to worship Bhagavan. As mentioned earlier, there are two divisions of scriptures in India, called ≈öruti or Veda (also called Nigama), and Smrti or Agama. Out of the four varnas of brahmana, ksatriya, vaisya, and sudra, only the first three classes are eligible to study and prac- tice the dharma propagated by the Vedas, as confirmed in Srimad Bhagavata (1.4.25). In contrast, however, every human being has the right to follow the dharma described in the Agamas. To look at it from a different perspective, there are two types of dharma - that related to the body and that related to the authen- tic self (atma). The karma-kanda division of the Vedas is concerned with the former. Only the first three varnas have the right to prac- tice it. The path of bhakti is concerned with the latter form of dharma, and it is open to all, because in terms of the ƒÅtmƒÅ, there is no difference between those who belong to the var·πáƒÅ≈õrama system and those who lie outside of its scope, often referred to pejoratively as mlecchas. The verses cited from Padma Purana clearly state that Vis≈Üu should be worshiped by all. This is also confirmed by sage Camasa (SB 11.5.3-4). By taking dik·π£ƒÅ according to the process described in the Agama, one becomes free of the limitations imposed by one’s low birth. Such a person attains the status of a dvija, the word commonly used for brahmanas, ksatriyas, and vaisyas after they have undergone the upanayana-sa·πÅskƒÅra. By Agamic dƒ´k≈üa, even a person of low birth becomes as respectable as a dvija. This is also affirmed by Devah≈´ti to Kapila (SB 3.33.6) in regard to those who chant the names of God. 521 Anuccheda 299 The Limbs of Arcanam 299.1 JanmƒÅ·π£·π≠amƒ´ ‡•®‡•Ø‡•Ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü- ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ IN THIS MANNER, arcanam has been described. The various limbs (angas) of worship can be learnt from books such as the ƒÄgamas. Other devotional practices, such as the celebration of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s birth, observance of vows during the month of Kartika, fasting on EkƒÅda≈õƒ´, and bathing during the month of Magha, are to be included as parts of arcanam. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á - Among these, Krsna’s birth celebration is described in a dialogue between Brahma and Narada in Vis≈Üu-rahasya: 1 ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•™‡•´ ‡•• All devotees without exception (api)’ should celebrate the birth of Bhagavan Krsna, the son of Devaki, for His satisfaction, by The word api is most commonly translated as “even.” This meaning, however, doesn’t quite fit the context of the statement. According to A Practical Dictionary of Sanskrit Grammar, “the word api is used sometimes to mean unqualified by condition.” The Bangiya-sabdakosa includes in its meanings of the word api “certainty” (niscaya), “emphasis” (niscayarthaka), and “totality” (samuccaya). All of these meanings are applicable here. any 522 299 The Limbs of Arcanam observing the appropriate vows with devotion and without miserliness in regard to expenditure. If a devotee does not observe this festival, he goes to hell for a period of fourteen Indras. (Vis≈Üu-rahasya)2 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ- And: ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•™‡•¨ ‡•• If a person gives up the celebration of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s birth and observes other vows instead, he derives none of their benefits that he may have heard about from scriptures or witnessed in others. (Vi≈ünu-rahasya)3 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•á ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•Æ/‡•ß‡•Ø‡•©‡•©‡•≠ ) - Non-miserliness (asathya) [i.e., liberality] in regard to expen- diture of wealth is described in the Eighth Canto of Srimad Bhagavata: ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ß‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•™‡•≠ ‡•• A person who utilizes wealth in five areas - for dharma, for renown, for investments to increase wealth, for fulfillment of desire, and for family - enjoys happiness in this life and the next. (SB 8.19.37) 2 4 tusty-artham devaki-s√ºnor jayanti-sambhavam vratam kartavyam vitt√§s√§·π≠hyena bhakty√§ bhakta-janair api akurvad yƒÅti nirayam yavad indras catur-dasa k·πõ·π£·πáa-janm√§·π£·π≠amim tyaktva yo’nyad vratam upasate napnoti sukrtam kincid drstam ≈õrutam athƒÅpi vƒÅ dharmaya yasase’rthaya kamaya svajanaya ca pa√±cadha vibhajan vittam ihamutra ca modate 523 III The Practice of Bhakti Commentary IN THIS ANUCCHEDA, Sri Jiva Gosvami concludes the discussion on deity worship, arcanam. This practice has many limbs, and to describe them all in detail would unnecessarily increase the size of the book. Therefore, he limits himself to some of the most important ones. Janma·π£·π≠ami, the birthday of Krsna, is celebrated all over the world, and it is one of the oldest commemorated birthdays. It is celebrated with great pomp and show in Vraja. Because Krsna is Svayam Bhagavan, His birthday celebration is more important than that of any other avatara. One should celebrate it without sparing any expense. Even a teacher the likes of SukracƒÅrya, who advised his student Bali not to honor his promise of giving three steps of land to Vamana Deva, says that one should use wealth for five purposes, one of which is dharma (SB 8.19.37, cited above). This is not to say that all these categories are to be taken as equal, but in any case, one must spend a portion of one’s earnings for religious purposes. For a devotee, this means services and cere- monies related to his or her worshipful deity. S≈´ta GosvƒÅmi, how- ever, has a different opinion from that of Sukracarya. According to him, wealth is meant only for dharma (arthasya dharmaikƒÅntasya, SB 1.2.9). 299.2 KƒÅrtika-vrata ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‚Äú‡§è‡§ï‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ- Next, we will describe the observance of vows during the month of Kartika, as discussed in Skanda Purana (2.4.1.21) in the follow- ing words: “The combined benefit of visiting all the holy places and executing all the yaj√±as with distribution of gifts cannot be 524 299 The Limbs of Arcanam compared even to one sixteenth of the result earned by observ- ing the vow of the Kartika month.” After this statement, the text goes on to say: ‡§è‡§ï‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§µ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•™‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•™‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ My dear boy, the month of Kartika is always especially dear to Bhagavan Kesava. Whatever pious acts one performs during this month for the sake of Vis≈Üu, bear imperishable results. O Narada, this is verily true. But one who passes the month of Kar- tika, which is so dear to Bhagavan Damodara, without observ- ing any vow for His pleasure, takes birth as an animal, being deprived of all dharma. (Skanda PurƒÅ≈Üa 2.4.1.23b-24)6 Commentary Kartika is the eighth month of the lunar year. It comes during October-November. It is also called Damodara, which is a name of Krsna. Krsna’s lila of being bound by ropes occurred during this month, and on this basis, it bears the name of Damodara (He whose belly, udara, was bound by ropes, dƒÅma). This festival is celebrated especially in V·πõndƒÅvana. Devotees from all over the world flock to VrndƒÅvana for one month to commemorate the occasion. They sing special prayers to Krsna and offer Him ghee lamps? 5 6 7 ekata·∏• sarva-tirthani sarve yajnah sadaksinah kƒÅrtikasya tu mƒÅsasya kala·πÅ n√§rhati sodasim ekata·∏• kartiko vatsa sarvada kesava-priyah yat-kincit kriyate punyam vi≈ünum uddisya kƒÅrtike tad-aksayam bhavet sarvam satyoktam tava nƒÅrada avratena ksiped yas tu masam damodara-priyam tiryag-yonim avapnoti sarva-dharma-bahiskrtah For more details on the Kartika-vrata, see chapter 16 of Hari-bhakti-vilƒÅsa. 525 III The Practice of Bhakti 299.3 EkƒÅda≈õƒ´ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä - ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á “‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§• ‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Next, we will discuss the observance of EkƒÅdasƒ´, or fasting on the eleventh day of the lunar month. This is a compulsory vow to be observed even by non-Vaisnavas. There are many general statements about EkƒÅda≈õƒ´, such as in Visnu-dharma: “Whether one is a devotee of Vis≈Üu or of the sun god, he must observe the vow of Ekadasi.’ “18 ‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‚Äú‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§• ‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ And in the Saura Purana: “Whether one is a devotee of Vis≈Üu, of ≈öiva, or of the sun god, one must observe the vow of EkƒÅdasi.” ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡•á ‚Äú‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø " ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å- More specific injunctions about Ekadasi can be found in Narada PancarƒÉtra. In the description of the duties that are compulsory after receiving dik≈üa, it is said, “I will explain to you the rules [regarding the observance of Ekadasi].“10 And then: ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≠‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•´‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ One should not eat on either of the Ekadasis that occur fort- nightly in the lunar month. One should remain awake through- out the night and worship Bhagavan with special attention. (Narada Pa√±caratra)“1 8 vaisnavo vatha sauro va kuryad ekadasi-vratam 9 vaisnavo vatha saivo va sauro’py etat 10 samayam≈õ ca pravaksyƒÅmi 11 ekadasyam na bhurjita pak·π£ayor ubhayor api jagaram nisi kurvita vi≈°esam carpayed vibhum 526 299 The Limbs of Arcanam ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç- In Vi≈ü≈Üu-yamala as well, there is a description of Ekadasi. After stating that one should not fast on mixed Ekadasi (dig-viddha, i.e., da≈õami-viddha),12 it is said: ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á ‡•• ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•´‡•Ø ‡•• One should not make any distinction between the Ekadasis that occur on the light and dark fortnights of the lunar month, think- ing that one of them need not be observed. One should not act irreligiously on the day of fast, and if able to, one should abstain even from light foods, like fruit. One should not per- form the ≈õraddha ceremony to the forefathers on the day of Eka- dasi. One should not pick tulasi leaves and should not sleep throughout the following day of Dvadasi [in completion of the vow]. (Vis≈Üu-yamala)13 ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡•á “‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä- ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The Vi≈ü≈Üu-yamala also forbids the bathing of Vis≈Üu during the day of DvƒÅdasƒ´. In the description of duties to be performed by Vaisnavas found in the Uttara-khanda of Padma PurƒÅ·πáa, it is said: “One should be firmly resolved to follow the vow of DvƒÅdasi [i.e., Ekadasi in general].” ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§∏‡•å‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ- And in the K√§si-khanda of Skanda Purana, in the section known as “The Glory of Saupar·πáa-dvƒÅrakƒÅ,” the brahmana Candra- ≈õarmƒÉ declares his vows concerning bhagavad-dharma: 12 The word dik or dig means “a direction,” such as east. Since Vedic cosmology counts ten directions (four cardinal points, four ordinal points, zenith, and nadir), the word dik also means “ten,” and it is used here in this 13 sense ‚Äî ‚ÄúEkadasƒ´ mixed with the tenth lunar day.” sukla-krsna-vibhedas casad-vyaparo vrate tatha saktau phaladi-bhuktis ca sraddham caikadasi-dine dvadasyam ca divasvapas tulasya vacayas tatha 527III The Practice of Bhakti ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•É‡§£‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡•§‡•§ ‡•Ø‡•´‡•® ‡•§‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§™‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§µ ‡•§ ‡•Ø‡•´‡•© ‡•§‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•å ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•´‡•™ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ O Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa, please hear what my duties are from now onward. I will not eat on EkƒÅda≈õƒ´, I will always remain awake during the night of Ekadasi, and every day I will worship You with great devotion. And if the lunar day of Ekadasi is over- lapped even fractionally by the day of Dasami [the tenth day of the lunar month], I will abstain from fasting on that day. For Your satisfaction, I will observe the eight MahƒÅ-dvƒÅdasƒ´ fasts. (Skanda Purana 7.4.24.32-33) 14 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡•á – Thus it is said in Agni Purana: ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•´‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ One should not eat on Ekadasi, because this is a great vow undertaken for Bhagavan Vi≈ü≈Üu. (Agni Purana)15 ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á- And in Gautamƒ´ya-tantra: ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•´‡•¨ ‡•§‡•§ 14 adya-prabhrti kartavyam yan maya krsna tac chrnu ekadasyam na bhoktavyam kartavyo jƒÅgara·∏• sadƒÅ maha-bhaktyatra kartavyam praty-aham pujanam tava palarddhen√§pi viddhan tu moktavyam vasaram tava tvat-prƒ´tyastau maya karya dvƒÅdasyam vrata-samyuta·∏• 15 The second and third lines of the verses cited here are different in the printed version. 15 ekƒÅdasyam na bhoktavyam tad-vratam vaisnavam mahat 528 299 The Limbs of Arcanam If due to negligence, a Vaisnava eats on EkƒÅdasi, his worship of Vi·π£·πáu becomes futile, and he will fall into a terrible hell. (Gautamiya-tantra 31.62b-63a)16 ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É- And in Matsya Purana and Bhavisya Purana: ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§°‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•´‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ One should fast on Ekadasi and eat on the following day of Dv√§- dasƒ´. The observance of EkƒÅdasi, whether it falls during the dark or light fortnight of the lunar month, is a great vow for the Vaisnavas. (Matsya Purana and Bhavisya Purana)1 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á- And in Skanda Purana: ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§π‡§æ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§π‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•´‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ One who eats on Ekadasi is a killer of his mother, father, brother, and preceptor. He will never attain the abode of Bhagavan Visnu. (Skanda Purana)18 ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó ‡§è‡§µ - ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á - The statements in this section regarding the Vaisnavas’ fast- ing on the day of Ekadasi specifically refer to abstinence from food grains offered to Bhagavan Vis≈Üu. There is no need to stip- ulate abstinence from food not offered to Vis≈Üu, because the Vaisnavas are ever-forbidden to partake of such food, as stated in Narada Pancaratra: 17 vaisnavo yadi bhunjita ekadasyam pramadatah visny arcanam v·πõtha tasya narakam ghoram apnuyat ekadasyam niraharo yad-bhunkte dvadasi-dine sukla va yadi va krsna tad-vratam vaisnavam mahat 18 matr-ha pitr-ha caiva bhratr-ha guru-ha tatha ekadasyam tu yo bhunkte visnu-loka-cyuto bhavet 529 III The Practice of Bhakti ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•´‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O Narada, food grains offered to Bhagavan Vi≈ü≈Üu are always for- bidden on Ekadasi for all devotees, headed by the Goddess RamƒÅ [Laksmi]. That this applies to others as well is thus all the more self-evident. (Narada Pa√±caratra) ¬ª ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á - In BrahmƒÅnda PurƒÅna, it is said: ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•å‡§∑‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§≠‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¨‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¨‡•ß ‡•• Whatever food one considers suitable for consumption, whether it be leafy vegetables, flowers, fruits, water, grains, beverages, or even medicine, should not be taken without first offering it to Bhagavan Vis≈Üu. If one eats without offering it to Vis≈Üu, he is liable to perform atonement. Thus, one should always eat after offering everything to Vis≈Üu. (Brahmanda Purana)20 ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§â‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á- Remaining awake throughout the night of Ekadasi is also a com- pulsory observance, as stated in a dialogue between UmƒÅ and Mahe≈õvara in Skanda Purana: ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¨‡•® ‡•• ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¨‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 19 prasadannam sada grahyam ekadasya·πÅ na narada 20 ramadi-sarva-bhaktanam itaresa·πÅ ca ka katha patram puspam phalam toyam anna-panadyam au·π£adham anivedya na bhunjita yadahƒÅrƒÅya kalpitam anivedya tu bhurjanah prayascitti bhaven narah tasmƒÅt sarvam nivedyaiva visnor bhurijita sarvada 530 299 The Limbs of Arcanam Those who do not remain awake throughout the night of Eka- da≈õƒ´, which is known as the day of Visnu, lose all piety. The same outcome results from the blasphemy of Vaisnavas. One who is not inclined to remain awake throughout the night of Dvadasi is ineligible to worship Bhagavan Kesava. (Skanda PurƒÅna 7.4.28.47a ) 21 ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á- Accordingly, observance of the vow of Ekadasi is pleasing to Vis≈Üu. This is indicated in the Uttara-khanda of Padma Purana: ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•Å ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¨‡•™ ‡•• O Goddess, hear from me the method of observing the vow of Dvadasi. By the mere remembrance of Dvada≈õƒ´, Bhaga- vƒÅn JanƒÅrdana [ Krsna] becomes pleased. ( Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda)22 ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á- And in Bhavisya PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¨‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The vow of EkƒÅda≈õƒ´ is highly meritorious, it dispels all sins, enhances one’s devotion to Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu, and bestows the supreme goal. ( Bhavisya Purana) 23 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•à‡§ï‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó- ‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ- ‡§£‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø- ‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ? 21 22 samprapte v√§sare vi≈ünor ye na kurvanti jagaram bhrasyate suk·πõtam te·π£am vaisnavanam ca nindaya matir na jayate yasya dvadasyam jƒÅgaram prati na hi tasyadhikaro’sti pujane kesavasya hi ≈õr≈Üu devi pravak·π£yami dvada≈õya≈õ ca vidhanakam tasya·∏• smarana-matrena santusto’bhuj janardanah 23 ekadasi maha-punya sarva-pƒÅpa-vinasinƒ´ bhaktes tu dipani visno·∏• paramartha-gati-pradƒÅ 531 III The Practice of Bhakti Consequently, by showing that devotees such as King Ambarƒ´≈üa, who were fixed exclusively in devotion and who ate only the remnants of food offered to Bhagavan, also observed Ekadasi, the Srimad Bhagavata also establishes that EkƒÅdasƒ´ is approved as an essential feature of Vai·π£·πáava dharma. It is also stated in the KƒÅrtika-mahatmya of Padma Purana that a brƒÅhma·πáa girl attained a status similar to that of Bhagavan’s beloved wife Satyabh√§m√§ by following the vows of EkƒÅdasi and Kartika. So what more need be said about the glory of Ekadasi? Commentary EkƒÅda≈õƒ´, the eleventh day of the lunar month, has a special signif- icance for devotees of Vis≈Üu. It is called the day of Vis≈Üu. There are two EkƒÅdasƒ´s every month, and one should fast on both of them. Some people make a distinction between the Ekadasis com- ing in the dark or bright fortnights and fast only on one of them. ≈örƒ´ Jiva Gosvami does not approve of this and says that even non- Vaisnavas, including the devotees of Siva or Durga, should fast on both Ekadasis. To observe Ekadasi completely, one should not eat on the eve of the fast. Then on the actual day of the fast, one should not eat or drink anything. On the following day, one should break the fast after sunrise and before the expiration of the prescribed time. On that day also, one should avoid eating at night. One should keep vigil on the night of the fasting day. But if one is unable to follow this rigorous program completely, one is permitted to take a light diet consisting of fruits, roots, and juices. Throughout the fast, one should remain engaged in the devotional practices of japa, kirtana, and reading or listening to scriptures, such as Bhagavata Purana. Eating grains, lentils, beans, and honey is completely forbidden. Sometimes the fast is held on the twelfth day instead of the eleventh. This occurs if the eleventh day is overlapped by the tenth (da≈õami-viddha), or on the basis of particular constellations (nak·π£a- tras). The time for breaking the fast also varies in accordance with the ending time of the lunar day of fasting or with the length of 532 299 The Limbs of Arcanam the twelfth day. One should follow the local calendar calculated according to local sunrise timings. Hari-bhakti-vilƒÅsa gives elabo- rate descriptions of the glories of Ekadasi-vrata - how to observe it, when to break the fast, when to fast on DvƒÅdasƒ´, and other such details. The Puranas are full of descriptions of the glories of the Eka- dasi fast and contain numerous stories concerning the benefits of fasting. The story of Satyabhama’s past life is described in the 89th chapter of the Uttara-khanda of Padma Purana. When ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa brought down the Parijata tree from heaven for Satyabhama, she was exceedingly happy and marveled at her great fortune. She asked K·πõ·π£·πáa, “What pious act or vow might I have observed in my past life by which I have obtained this fortune of being Your dearmost wife?” In the passage cited below, Krsna replied to her question, revealing to her the mystery of her former birth: At the end of Satyayuga, in the city of Mayapura [present day Haridvara] lived a pious brahmana named Atreya Deva ≈†arma. He was learned in the Vedas and devoted to guests, the fire, and the sun god. He worshiped the sun god regularly, and he himself had become effulgent like the sun. In his advanced age, his wife gave birth to a daughter named Gunavati. He married his daughter to his disciple, Candra Sarma. He had no son, but treated Can- dra exactly as his own son, and Candra was also very obedient to Atreya Deva. One day, they both went to the forest to gather some kusa grass and wood for a yajna. They were in the foothills of the Himalayas when a raksasa attacked and killed them both. By the influence of their worship and the holy land of Mayapura, they were both car- ried to Vaikuntha. When Gunavati heard that both her father and husband had been killed, she wailed and wept, feeling bereft of all shelter. She performed the funeral ceremony for both of them. Thereafter, she lived the rest of her life in devotion to Vis≈Üu, having full control over her senses and observing the vratas of Kartika and EkƒÅda≈õƒ´.24 24 For further details on the Ekadasi-vrata, read chapters 12 and 13 of Hari-bhakti-vilasa. 533 III The Practice of Bhakti As a consequence of observing these two vratas, she, in her follow- ing life, has now become you, My dearmost wife. (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda) It should be understood here that SatyabhƒÅmƒÅ is an eternal queen of ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa in Dvaraka, and no one else can take that position. Consequently, it is not that Gunavati herself became Satyabhama but that she was given the opportunity to merge into Satyabhama during Krsna’s manifest lila because of her vratas. 299.4 Bathing in the Month of Magha ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò‡§É ‡§∏‡•å‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‚Äì Now we will discuss the observance of vows during the month of Magha, as referred to in Garuda Purana: ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§∂‡§ö‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§• ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¨‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O Indra, chief of the gods and husband of Sacidevi, the month of Magha, which is so rare, is extremely dear to the Vaisnavas, the devas, the sages (rsis), and the contemplatives (munis). And it is especially dear to Bhagavan Madhava. (Garuda PurƒÅ≈Üa)25 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á- In Skanda Purana, in a dialogue between Brahma and Narada, it is said: ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¨‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 25 durlabho magha-mƒÅsas tu vaisnavƒÅnƒÅm ati-priyah devatƒÅnam ·πõ·π£ƒ´≈ÜƒÅm ca muninam sura-nayakah vi≈°e≈üe≈Üa sacƒ´-natha madhavasyati-vallabhah 534 299 The Limbs of Arcanam O Narada, every year one should bathe [before sunrise in a holy river like the Ganga] during the month of Magha, in order to nullify all one’s sins and to please Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa. (Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa)26 ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á- And in the Uttara-parva of Bhavisya Purana: ‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ó‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•¨‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ By giving up sense enjoyment and bathing early in the morn- ing during the month of Magha, a person ascends to his cov- eted abode of Bhagavan Visnu, accompanied by twenty-one generations of his family. (Bhavisya Purana, Uttara-parva)27 ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‚Äú‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ü‡§®‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø " ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The observance of other vows, such as Rama-navami and Vaisakha, are to be understood in corresponding manner. All these vows are ordained by describing the conduct of saints, as ≈öri Suka said about Vidura: “Wandering the earth, he observed vows (vratƒÅni) for the pleasure of Bhagavan Hari [Krsna]” (SB 3.1.19).28 ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø | ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§É ‡•• The word vratani refers to vows, such as Ekada≈õƒ´. This is a statement about Vidura, as is evident from the context. 26 27 sarva-papa-vinasaya krsna-santosa·πáƒÅya ca magha-snanam sadƒÅ karyam var·π£e varse ca narada ekavimsa-ganaih sarddham bhogan tyaktva yathepsitam magha-masy≈´sasi sn√§tvƒÅ vis≈Üu-lokam sa gacchati 28 gam paryatan… vratani cere hari-to·π£a·πáƒÅni 535 29 III The Practice of Bhakti Commentary Magha is the eleventh month in the lunar year and falls in January- February. For the entire month, practitioners of all persuasions bathe in a holy river or pond before sunrise. This is also the coldest month in North India. This vrata is especially observed at Prayaga, where holy men from all over India come and reside on the bank of the Ganga River for the whole month, while observing religious vows. Kumbha Mela, the world’s largest festival that takes place once every twelve years, also begins in Magha?” 29 ≈öri Jiva GosvƒÅmi does not provide elaborate details about the observance of Magha, because K·πõ·π£·πáa-bhaktas are more accus- tomed to the observances of Ekadasi-vrata, KƒÅrtika-vrata, and the appearance days of avataras, such as Bhagavan Rama. 536 For further details on Magha-vrata, read Hari-bhakti-vilasa (14.48-165). Anuccheda 300 Offenses in Deity Worship ‡•©‡•¶‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á " ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¨‡§π‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á - IT IS THUS understood that among all these vows, those that are specifically related to the worshipers’ respective cherished forms of Bhagavan must be duly observed by them. On this path consisting of service to Bhagavan’s feet (pada-sevƒÅ) and worship of Bhagavan (arcana), one should avoid all offenses. This refers to the thirty-two offenses described in the Agamas, such as the offense of entering a temple of Bhagavan wearing shoes or riding on a carriage! It also includes the thirty-two offenses described in VarƒÅha Purana (Chapter 116.5-36 ), begin - ning with eating the food of a king,2 and many other similar offenses spoken of by Bhagavan Varaha, such as the offense of seeking Bhagavan’s shelter while forsaking His scripture.3 ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§É || ‡•Ø‡•¨‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ 1 2 yanair vƒÅ padukair vapi gamanam bhagavad-grhe rajanna-bhak·π£a·πáam caivam 3 mama sastram bahiskrtya hy asmakam yah prapadyate 537III The Practice of Bhakti 4 That these offenses are to be avoided, is in accordance with this statement of Varaha Purana: O Earth Goddess, the offenses I have described along the path of My worship, should always be conscientiously avoided by a Vai·π£·πáava. (Varaha PurƒÅ·πáa)* ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•®‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•≠-‡•ß‡•Æ) - It is with this intention that Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa declared: ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•≠‡•¶ ‡•• Even water offered to Me with fidelity by a devotee is precious to Me. Yet, even lavish gifts bring Me no satisfaction when offered by a nondevotee. (SB 11.27.17B-18A)5 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å- ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• In the context of worship, the words ≈õraddha, “fidelity,” and bhakta, “[by] a devotee,” specifically enjoin an attitude of rev- erence (adara); whereas, all offenses are rooted in disregard (an√§dara), either for Bhagavan or His order. Therefore, the disrespect that is the breeding ground of all offenses must be thoroughly uprooted. Commentary THE THIRTY-TWO OFFENSES or prohibitions described in the Agama scriptures are cited in Hari-bhakti-vilƒÅsa (8.441-448). It is not known in which Agama they are originally found. They are as follows: mamarcan√§par√§dh√§ ye kirtyante vasudhe maya vaisnavena sada te tu varjaniyah prayatnata·∏• 5 sraddhayopahrtam prestham bhaktena mama vary api bh≈´ry apy abhaktop√§hrtam na me tosaya kalpate 538 300 Offenses in Deity Worship

  1. Entering the temple with shoes on. 2. Entering the temple in a vehicle.
  2. Not observing the festivals of Bhagavan.
  3. Not offering obeisance to the deity.
  4. Worshiping Bhagavan or praying before the deity without wash- ing the mouth and hands after eating, or with an unclean body. 6. Offering obeisance to Bhagavan in an unclean state.
  5. Offering obeisance with one hand only. Therefore, to avoid this offense, all hand-held objects should be set aside before offering obeisances.
  6. Turning around in a circle while standing in front of the deity. Some people in India do this because they consider it equivalent to performing parikrama of the deity.
  7. Spreading one’s legs and pointing one’s feet toward the deity while sitting in front of the deity.
  8. Sitting with one foot over the thigh in a half-lotus pose or with both knees folded together in front of the deity.
  9. Sleeping in front of the deity.
  10. Eating in front of the deity.
  11. Telling lies in front of the deity.
  12. Talking loudly in front of the deity. 15. Gossiping in front of the deity.
  13. Grieving in front of the deity.
  14. Punishing or blessing anyone in front of the deity.
  15. Admonishing anyone or using harsh words in front of the deity.
  16. Wrapping oneself in a blanket while serving the deity.
  17. Criticizing someone in front of the deity.
  18. Glorifying someone else in front of the deity.
  19. Using obscene words in front of the deity.
  20. Breaking wind in front of the deity.
  21. Offering useless articles to the deity, though capable of offering superior articles.
  22. Not offering seasonal fruits and vegetables.
  23. Eating without first offering one’s food to Bhagavan.
  24. Giving portions of eatables to someone first and then offering the rest to the deity.
  25. Sitting with one’s back toward the deity.
  26. Offering obeisance to someone else in front of the deity.
  27. Remaining silent when questioned by one’s guru. 539 III The Practice of Bhakti 6
  28. Praising oneself in front of the deity. 32. Criticizing the devas in front of the deity. The thirty-two offenses given in Varaha Purana (116.5-36) are summarized in Hari-bhakti-vilƒÅsa (8.449-459) as follows:
  29. Eating food received from kings or materialistic businessmen. 2. Touching the deity in the dark.
  30. Approaching the deity without observing proper etiquette.
  31. Opening the door to the deity’s temple without first clapping or ringing a bell.
  32. Offering food to the deity that has been seen by a dog or other animals.
  33. Breaking silence while worshiping the deity.
  34. Interrupting one’s worship to go out and pass stool or urine.
  35. Offering incense without first offering fragrance or scented garlands.
  36. Offering forbidden flowers, meaning those that are old, shriv- eled, rotten, already used for other purposes, unclean, or red- colored, except for roses.
  37. Serving the deity without cleaning the teeth or without bathing after having sexual union.
  38. Worshiping without bathing after touching a woman in her menstrual cycle or a dead body.
  39. Worshiping while wearing red, blue, or unclean clothes.
  40. Worshiping without bathing after seeing a dead body, visiting a crematorium, passing wind, or after applying oil on one’s own body.
  41. Worshiping while angry or in a state of indigestion, which leads. to burping, or while passing gas.
  42. Taking up the worship of the deity without respect for devotional scriptures.
  43. Preaching nondevotional scriptures.
  44. Chewing betel or gum in front of the deity.
  45. Worshiping the deity with flowers kept on the leaves of castor- oil plants. ≈örƒ´ Sanatana Gosvami writes as if he is citing directly from Varaha Purana, but the descriptions in the two books do not match, although the contents are the same. Either Sri Sanatana had a different reading or his list is to be taken as a summary of the Varaha Purana verses 116.5-36. 540 300 Offenses in Deity Worship
  46. Worshiping at forbidden times, such as at midnight.
  47. Worshiping while sitting on the bare floor or on a wooden seat. 21. Touching the deity with the left hand while bathing them. 22. Worshiping with stale flowers or flowers that had previously been promised to someone else.
  48. Spitting while worshiping.
  49. Boasting about one’s acts of worship.
  50. Putting on a curved or horizontal tilaka mark.
  51. Entering the temple without washing one’s feet?
  52. Offering food cooked by a nondevotee.
  53. Worshiping in front of nondevotees.
  54. Bathing the deity with water touched by the fingernails.
  55. Worshiping while the body is perspiring.
  56. Crossing over the articles offered to Bhagavan.
  57. Taking an oath in the name of Bhagavan. In Chapters 129 to 136, ≈örƒ´ Varaha Deva states the outcome of each particular offense, such as suffering in hell for a specific period of time and then taking birth in lower species. He also describes the appropriate atonement for each of the thirty-two offenses to the deity to enable the perpetrator to counteract the effect of an offense. The basic criterion of an offense is that it causes displeasure to the deity. The deity is to be seen as Bhagavan. The list of offenses should be taken as a guideline. One has to use common sense and follow the basic principles of etiquette that one naturally observes while relating with a highly honorable person, such as a king or the president of a country. Some of the rules are specifically related to Vedic culture, such as spreading one’s legs before the deity or eating in front of the deity. 7 This is often not possible to avoid when no facilities for washing the feet are available. 541 Anuccheda 301 Offenses to Devotees in the Matter of Worship ‡•©‡•¶‡•ß ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•©‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•®‡•ß ) - DISRESPECT (anƒÅdara) of highly realized devotees (mahat ), however, brings total ruin, as ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrada informed the Pracetas: ‡§® ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§á‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ß‡§®‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ß‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•≠‡•ß ‡•• Bhagavan Hari, who is a connoisseur of the aesthetic delight of divine love (rasa-jnah ) ’ and whose dearest loved ones (priya) are those who have abandoned all material wealth and whose only wealth is the Immanent Self (√§tma) [i.e., Bhagavan],2 does not accept the worship of those of polluted intellect, who, due to the pride of education, wealth, lineage, or accomplishments, disre- spect His authentic devotees (satsu), who are devoid of all sense of ego and possessiveness ( akincanesu ). ( SB 4. 31.21 ) 3 ‡§Ö‡§ò‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∑‡§ø‡§£ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π - ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§É || 1 3 ≈örƒ´ Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti comments that the compound rasa-jnah, referring to Bhagavan, means “He who is conversant with the aesthetic delight (rasa) of the prema of His devotees, who invest their sense of belongingness (mamata) in Him alone, giving up all attachment for wealth, children, and so on.‚Äù 2 Sridhara Svami na bhajati kumanisinam sa ijyam harir adhanatma-dhana-priyo rasa-jnah sruta-dhana-kula-karmanam madair ye vidadhati papam akincane≈üu satsu 542 301 Offenses to Devotees in the Matter of Worship The compound adhanatma-dhana-priya·∏• [referring to Bhaga- van Hari] means “He whose dearest loved ones (yasya priyah) are those who have abandoned all material wealth (adhanah) and whose only wealth is the Immanent Self (atma-dhanah).” The compound rasa-j√±a·∏• [also referring to Bhagavan Hari] means “He who is a relisher (rasikah) of the aesthetic delight of bhakti.” Who are those of polluted intellect (kumanƒ´·π£inƒÅ·∏•)? In anticipa- tion of this question, Narada answers in the second half of the verse that they are those who, due to the pride of education and so on, disrespect Bhagavan’s devotees. The word papam in this context refers to offenses (aparadham). Commentary To disrespect OR OFFEND a great devotee is more grievous than to disrespect the deity. Bhagavan can tolerate an offense commit- ted toward His own Self but not toward His devotee. Disrespect of devotees comes under the namƒÅparƒÅdhas described earlier (in Anuccheda 265). There is no separate atonement prescribed for such an offense. Either one has to supplicate the offended devotee or undergo the reaction. Offenses toward a devotee are so severe that even devotees on the perfectional stage of bhava (the first dawn- ing of divine love) can fall from that status, or their bhava can be demoted from a higher to a lower grade of being (BRS 1.3.54). ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrada hints at the root cause of this offensive mentality. He says that it is due to pride, which may arise due to various rea- sons, such as high birth, education, wealth, beauty, and notewor- thy accomplishments. Bearing this in mind, ≈örƒ´ Caitanya MahƒÅpra- bhu offered a golden rule to uproot the tendency toward offenses namely, by humility, tolerance, extending respect to others, and not hankering for respect. Sin (papam) means to engage in an act that is forbidden accord- ing to the Veda or Smrti scriptures. It is related to the law of karma. An offense (aparƒÅdha) is also a forbidden act, but it is associated with bhakti. Because bhakti is directly related to Bhagavan, an offense is directly displeasing to Him. Therefore, an offense is 543 III The Practice of Bhakti more damaging to its executor than a sin. Although these are two different things, the word papam is sometimes also used for an offense. 544 Anuccheda 302 Disrespect to a Great Devotee Results in Ruination ‡•©‡•¶‡•® ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•´/‡•ß‡•¶/‡•®‡•´ ) - MOREOVER, King Rahugana confessed to Sri Bharata: ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ñ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ô‡•ç ‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•≠‡•® ‡•• Although psycho-physical alterations [incited by my disrespect (mamƒÅvaj√±ƒÅ-k·πõta)]’ are altogether absent in you, who are a friend of the benefactor of the entire cosmos and devoid of all ego, being situated in absolute equality of vision, yet, even a king such as I, who wields the scepter of power like the trident- bearer Siva, will be instantly destroyed due to my disregard of a great devotee, such as you. (SB 5.10.25)2 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∞‡§π‡•Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• The meaning here is self-evident. 2 Sridhara Svami na vikriya vi≈õva-suhrt-sakhasya samyena vitabhimates tavapi mahad-vimanat sva-krtaddhi madrn nanksyaty ad≈´rƒÅd api sula-pani·∏• 545 III The Practice of Bhakti Commentary RAHUGANA states that Bhagavan is the benefactor of all. Moreover, He is the basis of His devotee’s establishment in equal vision. This implies that by His essential nature, He tolerates offenses toward Himself. But He is especially intolerant of an offense toward His dear devotee. Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa took a vow not to wield a weapon in the battle of Kuruksetra. But one day, when Arjuna’s life was in danger due to the ferocity of Bhisma’s fighting, He jumped down from Arjuna’s chariot and ran to attack Bhisma to protect His devotee. It is thus to be understood that an offense to a great devotee should be avoided at all costs. This does not mean that one can be disrespectful to beginning or intermediate level devotees. One should avoid offenses to all devotees. It is not easy to determine who is great and who is small. A humble-looking devotee may actually be a great devotee or may be on the way to becoming one. In fact, one should not disrespect anyone, devotee or nondevotee, knowing well that Paramatma resides within all beings. 546 Anuccheda 303 Arcanam Concluded 303.1 The Solution to Offenses ‡•©‡•¶‡•© ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å- IF, IN SPITE OF THIS understanding, one inadvertently commits an offense to Bhagavan, he should again engage in actions pleas- ing to Bhagavan, as stated by ≈örƒ´ Vyasa in the Avanti-khanda of Skanda PurƒÅna: ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Ö‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§†‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•≠‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Bhagavan Kesava certainly forgives the thirty-two types of offenses of a person who daily reads a chapter of the GitƒÅ. (Skanda PurƒÅna, Avanti- khanda ) 2 ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á.

And in the same PurƒÅ≈Üa, from the section known as Dvarak√§- mƒÅhƒÅtmya: ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•É‡§£‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§® ‡§∏ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§® ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•≠‡•™ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 1ahany ahani yo martyo gitadhyayam pathet tu vai dvatrimsad aparadhams tu k·π£amate tasya kesavah 547III The Practice of Bhakti A person who [daily] recites or even hears the glories of the thousand names of Visnu is never tainted even by thousands of offenses. (Skanda PurƒÅna, DvƒÅrakƒÅ mƒÅhƒÅtmya) 2 ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á- In the same Purana, from the RevƒÅ khanda: ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•≠‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Bhagavan Kesava forgives the thirty-two types of offenses of a person who, for the pleasure of Vis≈Üu, remains awake through- out the night of Dvadasi reciting the prayers to tulasi. (Skanda PurƒÅna, RevƒÅ khanda ) 3 ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ - Elsewhere in the same PurƒÅ≈Üa: ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•≠‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ One should sow tulasi, especially in the month of ≈örava≈Üa. Bha- gav√§n Purusottama forgives thousands of offenses of a person who does so. (Skanda Purana ) * ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á- In the same Purana, from the Kartika mƒÅhƒÅtmya: 2 3 4 ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•≠‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ sahasra-nama-mahatmyam yah pathec chrnuyad api aparadha-sahasre≈Üa na sa lipyet kadacana dvadasyam jagare visnor yah pathet tulasi-stavam dvatrimsad aparadhani k·π£amate tasya kesava·∏• tulasya ropanam karyam sravanena visesata·∏• aparadha-sahasrani k·π£amate purusottama·∏• 548 303 Arcanam Concluded Bhagavan Kesava forgives the thirty-two types of offenses of a person who worships the sacred Salagrama stone with tulasi leaves. (Skanda Purana, Kartika-mahatmya)” ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ - Elsewhere it is said: ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•≠‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Bhagavan Kesava always absolves thousands of offenses of a per- son who worships Bhagavan Hari while adorning his body with K·πõ·π£·πáa’s insignia of the conch, disc, club, and lotus.” ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•á- It is said in Adi-var√§ha Purana: 5 6 7 ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§∂‡•å‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•≠‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§Æ‡§•‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•Æ‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ A person who in the course of a year fasts and bathes in the Ganga at My sacred place known as Varaha-tirtha becomes puri- fied. One who does the same in Mathura is purified even if plagued by offenses. A virtuous person who renders service to either one of these holy places becomes free from offenses committed in thousands of births. (Adi-var√§ha Purana 177.25- 26)” tulasya kurute yas tu salagrama-silarcanam dvƒÅtrimsad aparƒÅdham≈õ ca k·π£amate tasya kesava yah karoti hare·∏• pujam krsna-sastrankito narah aparƒÅdha-sahasrani nityam harati kesava·∏• samvatsarasya madhye tu tirthe saukarake mama k·πõtopavasa·∏• snanena gangayam suddhim apnuyat mathurayam tathapy evam saparadhah sucir bhavet anayos tirthayor ekam yah sevetsuk·πõti narah sahasra-janma-janitan aparadhan jahati sa·∏• 549 III The Practice of Bhakti ‡§∂‡•å‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ü‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä- ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡•§ The word saukarake means “in the holy place known as S≈´kara- k≈üetra, the place where the boar avatara appeared.” It was already stated that an offense to a highly realized devotee (mahat) is absolved by propitiating him and obtaining forgive- ness, either through humble supplication or by continuously chanting the holy name for an extensive period in order to please him. Without pleasing the mahat whom one disregards, one cannot become free of the offense. ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™‡•§‡•≠‡•§‡•ß‡•´) - For this reason, Dak·π£a petitioned ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva in the following words: ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•å ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ ‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡§£‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•Æ‡•ß ‡•• Being blind to the truth of your identity, I wounded you in the assembly with the arrows of harsh speech, yet you disregarded my offense. I had plunged into the darkness of ignorance by offending you, the best of the honorable, but by your compas- sionate glance, you uplifted me. O venerable one, may you be at peace with me out of your own graciousness [as I have no power to counteract this offense on my own (na maya tat-pratikartum sakyam)]. (SB 4.7.15) ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ The same conclusion can be understood elsewhere as well. 8 5 yo’sau mayavidita-tattva-drsa sabhayam k≈üipto durukti-visikhair viganayya tan mƒÅm arvak patantam arhattama-nindayapad drsty√§rdraya sa bhagavan sva-k·πõtena tusyet The bracketed insert is Sridhara Svami’s comment. 550 303 Arcanam Concluded Commentary EARLIER (in Anuccheda 286), while discussing the gradations of liv- ing beings in terms of their eligibility to receive honor (pƒÅtras), ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi said that among all beings, humans are the best, and of them, the devotees, i.e., the Vaisnavas, are foremost. There- after, he concluded that the worshipful deity of the Vaisnavas is the supreme patra. Since the Vaisnavas and Bhagavan are the highest objects of honor, practitioners should be careful not to displease them. For this reason, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ warns us to avoid this at all costs. Offenses are bound to occur because of our ignorance and our physical and mental limitations. In this anuccheda, he offers dif- ferent scriptural solutions to counteract offenses against the deity as well as against a devotee. Unless one becomes free of offenses, one will not experience the full potency of bhakti. If an offense is committed against a devotee, then unless he or she is pacified, one does not become free of the offense. In this con- text, ≈öri Jiva gives the example of Daksa, who offended ≈öiva by his piercing criticism. Later he realized his mistake and begged par- don from ≈öiva. Even after an offense is forgiven, the tendency to commit offenses remains, just as by atonement, although the ill- effect of a sinful deed can be annulled, yet the tendency to repeat the same act remains. This is seen from the example of Daksa, who offended Sri Narada in his next life, wherein he was also named Dak·π£a. Consequently, one has to be very careful not to repeat the same offense again. As one assiduously engages in devotion while avoiding offenses, one’s tendency to commit an offense will also fade away. 551 6 Vandanam Anuccheda 303.2 303 Arcanam Concluded 303.2 Vandanam As an Independent Practice ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äì ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡§æ- ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ Now we will examine vandanam, or offering obeisance to Bhaga- v√§n. Although offering obeisance also falls under the category of worship (arcanam), it has been prescribed separately in order to show that it stands as an independent practice, like singing (kirtanam) and remembering (smaranam) the glories of Bhaga- v√§n. This same principle applies in the case of other devotional practices as well. ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§¶‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡•§ Vandanam is prescribed separately for devotees who, after hear- ing about the unlimited virtues and majesty of Bhagavan, feel themselves unfit to render service to Bhagavan’s feet, to medi- tate on His qualities, or to engage in other practices. They exert their full attention simply in offering obeisance (namaskƒÅra) to Bhagavan. This very namaskara is also counted as worship (arcana) of Bhagavan. ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•á- An example of the separate prescription of vandanam is found in Nrsimha Purana: ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•Æ‡•® ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The sacrifice (yaj√±a) of offering obeisance to Bhagavan is con- cluded to be the best of all types of sacrifice. Merely by once bow- ing down to Bhagavan with eight limbs of the body, one attains Bhagavan Hari. (Nrsimha Purana)” 9 namaskƒÅra·∏• smrto yaj√±a·∏• sarva-yajne·π£u cottamah namaskƒÅre≈Üa caikena sƒÅ·π£·π≠ƒÅngena harim vrajet 555 III The Practice of Bhakti ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•ß‡•™‡•§‡•Æ) - An example of vandanam is found in Brahma’s statement to Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa: ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§® ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ß‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•Æ‡•© ‡•• Therefore (tat), a person who sympathetically anticipates Your grace [consistently reflecting, “when will Your mercy be upon me?” (kada bhavata·∏• daya bhavi·π£yatƒ´ti bahu manyama·πáa·∏•)],10 who endures the results of his own past deeds [without attach- ment (anasakta·∏• san sahamana·∏• eva)], and who lives by bowing down to you with his heart, speech, and body, inherits You, the ultimate refuge of liberation (mukti-pade). (SB 10.14.8)11 ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‚Äú‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç” ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ | ‡•ß‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•≠ ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å- ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ In this verse, the pronoun tat means tasmat, “therefore.” The syntactical connection between this and the previous verse is as follows - “because (yasmat) You are self-endowed with tran- scendental qualities, the extent of which cannot be estimated, therefore (tasmat) the devotee bows down to You with his heart, speech, and body.” [We cite here the previous verse in full:] 10 O Bhagavan, who can measure the extent of the qualities present in You, who are intrinsically self-endowed with tran- scendental qualities (gun√§tmanah)12 and who avatarically descend for the well-being of this entire world? The dust par- ticles upon the earth, the dew drops in the sky, and the rays of light in the constellations could possibly be calculated after This and the next bracketed insert are Sridhara Svami’s comments. “tat te’nukampam susamik·π£amano bhurjana ev√§tma-k·πõtam vipakam hrd-vag-vapubhir vidadhan namas te jiveta yo mukti-pade sa daya-bhak 12 In Krama-sandarbha, Sri Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi comments that the compound gunatmana·∏• means that Bhagavan’s qualities are intrinsic to His essential being (svarupa-bhuta) and that they are eternal (nitya) and transcendental (aprak·πõta). The translation is rendered accordingly. 556 303 Arcanam Concluded many births by some who are exceptionally skilled, but even they could not estimate Your qualities. (SB 10.14.7)13 ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§¶‡§∂‡§Æ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡•§ In SB 10.14.8, the word nama·∏• means “obeisance” (namaskƒÅram). In the compound mukti-pade, “the ultimate refuge of libera- tion,” the word mukti refers to the ninth subject out of the ten primary topics of Srimad Bhagavata, and pada refers to the com- plete manifestation of the tenth subject, the ultimate refuge (√§≈õraya) even of liberation. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§π ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø - ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§ü‡§® ‡§á‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∏ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∂‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ Alternatively, the word mukti here can mean “divine love” (prema), in accordance with the prose of the Fifth Canto [i.e., SB 5.19.19-20, discussed in Anuccheda 234]. In this case, mukti- pade would mean “He who is the object (visaya) of the devotee’s prema.” Brahma’s statement would then mean that the devotee who bows to you inherits You [≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa], who are Bhagavan in His uttermost completion and the object of divine love.
